Genk|Genk]] |youthyears2 = 2010–2012 |youthclubs2 = [[Lille OSC|Lille]] |years1 = 2012–2013 |clubs1 = [[Lille OSC|Lille B]] |caps1 = 11 |goals1 = 2 |years2 = 2012–2014 |clubs2 = [[Lille OSC|Lille]] |caps2 = 40 |goals2 = 6 |years3 = 2014– |clubs3 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] |caps3 = 58 |goals3 = 14 |years4 = 2014–2015 |clubs4 = → [[Lille OSC|Lille]] (loan) |caps4 = 33 |goals4 = 8 |years5 = 2017–2018 |clubs5 = → [[VfL Wolfsburg]] (loan) |caps5 = 31 |goals5 = 6 |nationalyears1 = 2010 |nationalteam1 = [[Belgium national youth football team|Belgium U15]] |nationalcaps1 = 2 |nationalgoals1 = 0 |nationalyears2 = 2010–2011 |nationalteam2 = [[Belgium national youth football team|Belgium U16]] |nationalcaps2 = 9 |nationalgoals2 = 1 |nationalyears3 = 2011 |nationalteam3 = [[Belgium national under-17 football team|Belgium U17]] |nationalcaps3 = 1 |nationalgoals3 = 0 |nationalyears4 = 2012–2013 |nationalteam4 = [[Belgium national under-19 football team|Belgium U19]] |nationalcaps4 = 19 |nationalgoals4 = 10 |nationalyears5 = 2014–2015 |nationalteam5 = [[Belgium national under-21 football team|Belgium U21]] |nationalcaps5 = 2 |nationalgoals5 = 0 |nationalyears6 = 2014– |nationalteam6 = [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] |nationalcaps6 = 25 |nationalgoals6 = 3 |club-update = 10:02, 27 February 2019 (UTC) |ntupdate = 14 November 2017 (UTC) }} '''Divock Okoth Origi''' ({{IPA-all|diˈvɔk ɔˈkɔθ oˈrigiː|[[Kenyan English]]:|Divock Origi pronunciation.ogg}}; born 18 April 1995) is a Belgian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Forward|forward]] for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and the [[Belgium national football team|Belgium national team]]. He is the son of former Kenyan professional footballer [[Mike Origi]].
Origi began his career at [[Lille OSC|Lille]], and scored on his professional debut for them in 2013. A year and a half later, he was signed for £10 million by Liverpool, who loaned him back to Lille for the [[2014–15 Ligue 1]] season.
Origi made his international debut for Belgium in 2014, and was part of their team which reached the quarter-finals of the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]], during which he became the youngest goalscorer in Belgian World Cup history.
==Club career==
===Early career=== Origi began his career playing football at [[K.R.C. Genk|Genk]]'s youth academy where he spent nine years before signing for [[LOSC Lille|Lille]] in May 2010, aged 15, after turning down an approach by [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/origi-turning-down-manchester-united-10994105|title=Origi: Why turning down United and ending up at Liverpool was best thing for me|last=Doyle|first=Ian|website=liverpoolecho|access-date=2016-03-11}}</ref>
===Lille=== [[File:Divock Origi (LOSC Lille).JPG|thumb|left|358x358px|Origi playing for Lille in 2014]] On 24 January 2013, Origi was an unused substitute in Lille's 3–1 away win over [[Stade Plabennecois|Plabennec]] in a [[2012–13 Coupe de France|2012–13]] [[Coupe de France]] match.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/lacklustre-lille-held-at-home.htm |title=Lacklustre Lille held at home |date=2 February 2013 |publisher=Ligue de Football Professionnel |accessdate=5 February 2013 |archivedate=17 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517121120/http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/lacklustre-lille-held-at-home.htm |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> Nine days later, he scored on his competitive debut for the senior Lille side, coming on as a substitute in the 69th minute for [[Ronny Rodelin]] and scoring to bring his side from 1–0 down against [[Troyes AC|Troyes]].<ref>{{cite web |language=fr |date=3 February 2013 |url=http://www.losc.fr/actualite-foot-lille/ligue-1/b-pedretti-origi-le-rayon-de-soleil-de-la-soiree |title=B. Pedretti : "Origi, le rayon de soleil de la soirée" |publisher=Lille OSC |accessdate=5 February 2013 |archivedate=17 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517154355/http://www.losc.fr/actualite-foot-lille/ligue-1/b-pedretti-origi-le-rayon-de-soleil-de-la-soiree |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |accessdate=5 February 2013 |date=4 February 2013 |url=http://www.futaa.com/football/article/divock-origi-scores-on-ligue-1-debut-for-lille |title=Divock Origi scores on Ligue 1 debut for Lille |author=Patrick Korir |publisher=Futaa.com |archivedate=17 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140517121707/http://www.futaa.com/football/article/divock-origi-scores-on-ligue-1-debut-for-lille |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
===Liverpool=== On 29 July 2014, [[Premier League]] club [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] announced that they had completed a £10 million transfer for Origi, who signed a five-year contract but was immediately loaned back to Lille for the [[2014–15 Ligue 1|2014–15 season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/167369-reds-complete-origi-deal|title=Reds complete Origi deal|date=29 July 2014|publisher=Liverpool F.C.|accessdate=29 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28551650 |title=Liverpool sign Belgium striker Divock Origi from Lille for £10m |date=29 July 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=29 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140729230536/http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/28551650 |archivedate=29 July 2014 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
====2014–15 season: Loan to Lille==== In his first match back in Lille, Origi scored his first goal of the new Ligue 1 season through a penalty against [[Stade Malherbe Caen|Caen]] to secure a 1–0 win for his side. This was after he had been brought down in the box by defender [[Dennis Appiah]], who was sent off by the referee towards the 70th minute.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/321521/report |title=Ligue report: Lille let off the hook |date=15 August 2014 |publisher=Sky Sports |accessdate=17 August 2014}}</ref>
On 11 December 2014, as Lille lost 0–3 at home to [[VfL Wolfsburg]] to be eliminated from the [[2014–15 UEFA Europa League group stage|UEFA Europa League group stage]], Origi had a penalty saved by [[Diego Benaglio]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Holyman|first1=Ian|title=LOSC left high and dry by Wolfsburg|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2015/matches/round=2000587/match=2014565/postmatch/report/index.html|accessdate=11 December 2014|publisher=UEFA|date=11 December 2014}}</ref> On 15 March 2015, Origi scored a [[hat-trick]] for Lille in a 3–0 league win against [[Stade Rennais F.C.|Rennes]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.espnfc.com/french-ligue-1/match/393429/lille-stade-rennes/report |title=Origi back with a bang in Lille win |publisher=ESPN FC |date=15 March 2015 |accessdate=15 March 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/feuille_match/79062 Lille 3–0 Rennais Match Report]</ref>
====2015–16 season==== [[File:Goal from Divock Origi (19128014363).jpg|thumb|right|333px|Origi (left) in action for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] against the [[Thai Premier League All-Star Football|Thai All-Stars]] in 2015|285x285px]] On 11 July 2015, Origi was named in Liverpool's 30-man squad for their pre-season tour of Thailand, Australia and Malaysia. In his non-competitive debut for Liverpool, a pre-season friendly against [[Thai Premier League All-Star Football|Thai All-Stars]] on 14 July, Origi scored his first goal for the club in a 4–0 win.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpool-fc-4-0-thai-stars-9656001|title= Liverpool FC 4–0 Thai All Stars: Origi nets debut goal as monsoon fails to dampen Reds' pre-season stroll|date=14 July 2015|newspaper=Liverpool Echo|accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref>
His first competitive game for the team was on 12 September, replacing [[Danny Ings]] for the final sixteen minutes of a 3–1 loss at [[Liverpool F.C.–Manchester United F.C. rivalry|rivals]] [[Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=McNulty|first1=Phil|title=Man Utd 3–1 Liverpool|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34160795|accessdate=2 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=12 September 2015}}</ref> Origi scored his first competitive Liverpool goals on 2 December, a hat-trick in a 6–1 away win over [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in the quarter-finals of the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Southampton 1–6 Liverpool|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34918281|accessdate=2 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 December 2015}}</ref> Eleven days later, he scored his first Premier League goal, replacing the injured [[Dejan Lovren]] in the 79th minute and scoring an added-time equaliser from outside the penalty area for a 2–2 draw against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] at [[Anfield]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dawkes|first1=Phil|title=Liverpool 2–2 West Brom|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35018987|accessdate=13 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=13 December 2015}}</ref> On 14 February, he scored his second league goal against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] in a 6–0 victory, only 27 seconds after replacing [[Daniel Sturridge]] in the second half; this was the fastest goal scored by a substitute that season.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35515112|title=Aston Villa 0–6 Liverpool|date=14 February 2016|publisher=BBC Sport|last1=Sanghera|first1=Mandeep|accessdate=14 February 2016}}</ref>
On 7 April 2016, Liverpool manager [[Jürgen Klopp]] surprisingly started Origi ahead of Sturridge (the team's first-choice striker) during Liverpool's [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League knockout phase|Europa League quarter-final]] match against [[Borussia Dortmund]], Klopp's former side. Origi scored a vital away goal in [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League knockout phase#Borussia Dortmund v Liverpool|the 1–1 draw]]. Three days later, he scored two goals in a 4–1 win over [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] after coming on as a substitute to replace [[Sheyi Ojo]] at half-time.
====2016–17 season==== Origi was used predominantly as a substitute and cup player at the start of [[2016–17 Liverpool F.C. season|the 2016–17 campaign]]. He scored his first goal of the season on 23 August 2016 in a 5–0 [[2016–17 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]] win over [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3755142/Burton-0-5-Liverpool-Divock-Origi-Daniel-Sturridge-Roberto-Firmino-score-EFL-Cup.html|title=Burton 0–5 Liverpool: Divock Origi, Roberto Firmino and Daniel Sturridge find the back of the net as Reds ease into EFL Cup third round|website=Daily Mail|last=King|first=Dominic|date=23 August 2016|accessdate=30 November 2016}}</ref> He scored his first [[2016–17 Premier League]] goal on 26 November, coming off the bench for the injured [[Philippe Coutinho]] to score the opener in a 2–0 win over [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/11/26/premier-league-clockwatch-liverpool-vs-sunderland-rest-3pm-kick/|title=Liverpool 2 Sunderland 0: Divock Origi provides relief after Philippe Coutinho is stretchered off|website=Telegraph|last=Findon|first=Ben|date=26 November 2016|accessdate=30 November 2016}}</ref>
====2017–18 season: Loan to VfL Wolfsburg==== On 31 August 2017, [[Bundesliga]] club [[VfL Wolfsburg]] announced the signing of Origi on a season-long loan deal.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.vfl-wolfsburg.de/en/info/news/detailspage/artikel/welkom-divock-origi-47146.html|title=Welkom, Divock Origi! |website=vfl-wolfsburg.de|date=31 August 2017|accessdate=31 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/liverpools-divock-origi-joins-wolfsburg-in-6m-season-long/13zpa1prlvhfw1k7zy6spcfxkw|title=Liverpool's Divock Origi joins Wolfsburg in £6m season-long loan deal {{!}} Goal.com|access-date=2018-06-13|language=en}}</ref>
====2018–19 season: Return to Liverpool==== On 2 December, Origi scored his first goal of the season in [[Merseyside derby|a derby match]] against city rivals [[Everton F.C.|Everton]], which Liverpool won 1–0. Origi came on as a substitute for [[Roberto Firmino]] in the 84th minute and scored with a header in the 96th minute, capitalising on an error from Everton goalkeeper [[Jordan Pickford]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/328060-match-report-liverpool-everton|title=Origi saves the day{{!}}|date=2 December 2018|publisher=Liverpool F.C.|accessdate=2 December 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Origi has represented Belgium at [[Belgium national youth football team|under-15]], [[Belgium national youth football team|under-16]], [[Belgium national under-17 football team|under-17]], [[Belgium national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[Belgium national under-21 football team|under-21]] level. He scored ten goals while in the under-19 team, the first in a [[2013 UEFA European Under-19 Championship qualification]] match against [[Belarus national under-19 football team|Belarus]] on 12 October 2012.
The [[Football Kenya Federation]] expressed an interest in persuading Origi to play for the [[Kenya national football team|Kenya senior national team]] in the future.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-ke/news/4522/kenya/2013/02/04/3726151/kenya-fa-reveal-they-will-lure-striker-divock-origi-to-play?ICID=HP_MR_2 |title=Kenya FA reveal they will lure striker Divock Origi to play for Harambee Stars |date=4 February 2013 |first=David |last=Kwalimwa |publisher=Goal.com |accessdate=5 February 2013 |archivedate=8 February 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208060847/http://www.goal.com/en-ke/news/4522/kenya/2013/02/04/3726151/kenya-fa-reveal-they-will-lure-striker-divock-origi-to-play?ICID=HP_MR_2 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> However, on 13 May 2014, [[Belgium national football team|Belgium senior national team]] manager [[Marc Wilmots]] announced Origi would be part of the 23-man squad representing Belgium at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/27395150 |title=Adnan Januzaj included in Belgium's World Cup squad |date=13 May 2014 |accessdate=13 May 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |archivedate=1 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140701141133/http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/27395150 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
Origi came on as a substitute for [[Romelu Lukaku]] in the 58th minute of the opening [[2014 FIFA World Cup Group H|Group H]] game against [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] in [[Belo Horizonte]] on 17 June. In Belgium's second match, again after coming on as a substitute for Lukaku, he scored his first senior international goal in the 88th minute of a 1–0 win over [[Russia national football team|Russia]] to qualify the ''Red Devils'' for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup knockout stage|knockout stage]].<ref name=bbc>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25285242 |title=Belgium v Russia |first=Graham |last=Chase |date=22 June 2014 |accessdate=22 June 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |archivedate=8 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140708204715/http://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/25285242 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> In so doing, at 19 years, 2 months and 4 days, he became the youngest goalscorer of the tournament (until [[United States national men's soccer team|American]] winger [[Julian Green]] scored against Belgium during their [[2014 FIFA World Cup knockout stage#Belgium vs United States|round of 16 match]]), the youngest goalscorer in Belgian World Cup history, and the first player of Kenyan origin to score at a [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup finals]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2105895-divock-origis-late-goal-for-belgium-defeats-russia |title=Divock Origi's Late Goal for Belgium Defeats Russia |publisher=Bleacher Report |first=Sean |last=Swaby |date=22 June 2014 |accessdate=22 June 2014 |archivedate=10 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140710225439/http://bleacherreport.com/articles/2105895-divock-origis-late-goal-for-belgium-defeats-Russia |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> For his performances, he was named the Young Talent of the 2014 [[Belgian Sportsman of the year]] awards.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en-ke/news/4522/kenya/2014/12/16/7122662/origi-scoops-belgiums-award-for-most-promising-youngster|title=Lille loanee Divock Origi has won Belgium’s award for most Promising Youngster of the Year 2014 as Liverpool summer signing continues to impress|accessdate=2 December 2015|publisher=Goal.com|date=16 December 2014}}</ref>
Origi scored once in Belgium's successful [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]] campaign, in a 6–0 home win over [[Andorra national football team|Andorra]] on 10 October 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chambers|first1=Miles|title=Belgium 6–0 Andorra: De Bruyne and Mertens bag doubles in record-equalling win|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/match/belgium-vs-andorra/1653181/report|accessdate=2 December 2015|publisher=Goal.com|date=10 October 2014}}</ref> He was included in the squad for [[UEFA Euro 2016|the final tournament]], but missed out on the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>https://www.skysports.com/football/news/29908/11380541/radja-nainggolan-left-out-of-belgium-world-cup-squad</ref>
==Personal life== Origi was born in [[Ostend]] and grew up in [[Houthalen-Helchteren|Houthalen-Oost]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nieuwsblad.be/article/detail.aspx?articleid=BLBOZ_01167498 |title=Mike Origi: 'Natuurlijk zijn we fier op Divock' |date=4 July 2014 |newspaper=Het Nieuwsblad |location= |accessdate=22 July 2014 |language=nl |archivedate=27 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140727074127/http://www.nieuwsblad.be/article/detail.aspx?articleid=BLBOZ_01167498 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> He was born into a family of footballers. His father, [[Mike Origi]], played for [[KV Oostende]] (at the time Divock was born) and Genk, among other Belgian clubs, as well as the Kenya national team. His uncle, Austin Oduor, played for [[Gor Mahia F.C.|Gor Mahia]] in the [[Kenyan Premier League]] while his other uncles, Gerald and Anthony, played for [[Tusker F.C.|Tusker]].<ref>[http://kenyafootball.com/index.php?doc=story&id=1033&categ=1 Mike Okoth Origi: The unsung grandmaster of Kenyan Soccer] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006140034/http://kenyafootball.com/index.php?doc=story&id=1033&categ=1 |date=6 October 2007 }}</ref> His cousin [[Arnold Origi|Arnold]] currently plays for [[Lillestrøm SK|Lillestrøm]] in the Norwegian [[Tippeligaen]] and the Kenya national team as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]]. The Origi family is of [[Kenyans|Kenyan]] [[Luo people|Luo]] ethnicity.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.standardmedia.co.ke/worldcup/article/2000126369/divock-origi-proud-of-kenyan-heritage-speaks-kiswahili-and-four-luo-words|title=In footsteps of his father: Belgium star Divock Origi proud of Kenyan heritage, speaks Kiswahili and four Luo words|date=29 June 2014 |first=Robin|last=Toskin|newspaper=The Standard|location=Nairobi|accessdate=5 July 2014}}</ref>
On 25 June 2014, a baby dolphin at the [[Boudewijn Seapark]] in [[Bruges]] was baptised "Origi" in Divock Origi's honour after having scored the winning goal against Russia during Belgium's group stage match at the 2014 World Cup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rtl.be/info/votreregion/flandre/1103384/origi-debarque-a-bruges- |title=Origi débarque à Bruges! |language=fr |date=25 June 2014 |publisher=RTL Television |accessdate=28 June 2014 |archivedate=10 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140710225210/http://www.rtl.be/info/votreregion/flandre/1103384/origi-debarque-a-bruges- |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sporza.be/cm/sporza/voetbal/Rode_Duivels/1.2011524 |title=Dolfijntje "Origi" geboren in Boudewijn Seapark |language=nl |date=25 June 2014 |accessdate=22 July 2014 |publisher=Sporza |archivedate=26 July 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140726202914/http://sporza.be/cm/sporza/voetbal/Rode_Duivels/1.2011524 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>

He began his professional career with [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]] in 2009, and was part of their teams that won the [[DFB-Pokal]] and [[DFL-Supercup]] in 2011. He totalled 258 competitive appearances and 23 goals before moving to Liverpool on a free transfer in 2016.
Born and raised in Germany, he represented his father's Cameroon at international level and played for them at the [[2010 Africa Cup of Nations]] and the [[FIFA World Cup]]s of [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010]] and [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014]].
==Club career== ===Early career=== Born in [[Bochum]], Matip began his career with SC Weitmar 45 before joining [[VfL Bochum]] in 1997.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.schalke04.de/?id=5065 | title = Joël Matip | language = German | publisher = FC Schalke 04 | accessdate = 5 August 2012}}</ref> After three years in VfL Bochum's youth teams, Matip was scouted by Schalke 04 in July 2000.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.kicker.de/news/fussball/bundesliga/vereine/1-bundesliga/2012-13/fc-schalke-04-2/57147/spieler_matip-joel.html | title = Matip, Joel | language = German | publisher = kicker.de | accessdate = 5 August 2012}}</ref>
===FC Schalke 04=== {{expand section|date=September 2018}} [[File:Joel Matip 2010.jpg|left|thumb|311x311px|Matip with [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]] during a pre-season training session, in July 2010.|alt=]] Matip made his professional debut on 17 October 2009 in a [[Regionalliga]] against [[1. FC Saarbrücken]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.reviersport.de/articles-97252.html | title = Sonntagsschuss bricht das Genick | language = German | publisher = reviersport.de | date = 17 October 2009 | accessdate = 5 August 2012}}</ref> He made his [[Bundesliga]] debut for Schalke on 7 November 2009 against [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]], in which he scored the game-tying goal and was subsequently named [[man of the match]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://sportbild.bild.de/SPORT/bundesliga/2009/11/07/bayern-schalke/felix-magath-bubi-matip-trifft-louis-van-gaal-wieder-ohne-sieg.html | title = Wieder kein Sieg! Bayern weiter in der Krise | language = German | publisher = bild.de | date = 7 November 2009 | accessdate = 5 August 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.goal.com/de/news/827/bundesliga/2009/11/07/1610570/man-of-the-match-joel-matip | title = Man of the Match: Joel Matip | language = German | publisher = goal.com | date = 7 November 2009 | accessdate = 5 August 2012}}</ref>
On 2 March 2010, Matip signed a three-and-a-half-year contract with [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ontheminute.com/news/news.php?news=21504 | title = Schalke starlet signs new deal | publisher = ontheminute.com | date = 2 March 2010 | accessdate = 5 August 2012}}</ref>
In January 2012, Schalke announced that Matip signed a two-year contract extension running until 30 June 2016.
On 23 February 2013, Matip scored both goals as Schalke recorded an important 2–1 victory over [[Fortuna Düsseldorf]], securing the club's second win in 12 games.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/report/346200/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901 |title= Schalke 04 2–1 Fortuna Düsseldorf |publisher=ESPNFC |date=23 February 2013 | accessdate = 9 June 2013}}</ref>
===Liverpool=== On 15 February 2016, Matip announced signing a four-year pre-contract agreement to join [[Liverpool Football Club|Liverpool]] on a free transfer, following the expiration of his contract with Schalke.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/feb/15/joel-matip-liverpool-schalke-transfer-signing | title = Schalke confirm Joel Matip to join Liverpool F.C. in summer | publisher = theguardian.com | date = 16 February 2016 | accessdate = 16 February 2016}}</ref>
On 1 July 2016, Matip officially became a Liverpool player, taking the shirt number 32, whilst [[Cameron Brannagan]], who previously wore 32 took number 25.
==== 2016–17 season ==== Matip made his debut for Liverpool on 23 August 2016 against [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]] in the [[2016–17 EFL Cup|League Cup]] in a 5–0 win for the Reds.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/232883-liverpool-hit-five-to-see-off-burton-in-efl-cup | title = Liverpool hit five to see off Burton in EFL Cup | publisher = LiverpoolFC.com | date = 23 August 2016 | accessdate = 23 August 2016}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the club in a 4–2 Premier League win over [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] at [[Selhurst Park]] on 29 October.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Matip|first1=Joël|title=crystal-palace-vs-liverpool-live-match-day-blog|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/match/2016-17/first-team/crystal-palace-vs-liverpool-live-match-day-blog|website=www.liverpoolfc.com|publisher=LiverpoolFC.com|accessdate=30 October 2016}}</ref> Matip was voted as Standard Chartered Player of the Month for his performances in November.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/246123-joel-matip-scoops-player-of-the-month-award|title=Joel Matip scoops Player of the Month award|work=Liverpool FC|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref>
Matip was withdrawn from the fixture against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] on 15 January 2017, as Liverpool were yet to get full clarity from [[FIFA]] over his eligibility, and also as a result of the [[Cameroonian Football Federation|Cameroon Football Federation]] failing to confirm that Matip can therefore play club football during the [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/250478-liverpool-fc-statement-on-joel-matip|title=Liverpool FC statement on Joel Matip|work=Liverpool FC|access-date=2018-07-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.foxsports.com/soccer/story/liverpool-joel-matip-cameroon-fifa-011717|title=Why can't Joel Matip play for Liverpool? Explaining the confusion|date=2017-01-17|work=FOX Sports|access-date=2018-07-08|language=en-US}}</ref> Overall, Matip was considered as a key player to improving Liverpool's defence, which had received extreme criticism prior to the season,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/09/15/jurgen-klopp-stop-criticising-liverpools-defence-trust-improve/|title=Jurgen Klopp: Stop criticising Liverpool's defence - I trust them to improve|last=Bascombe|first=Chris|date=2017-09-15|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-07-08|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}}</ref> during the [[2016–17 Liverpool F.C. season|2016–17 season]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thisisanfield.com/2017/05/liverpool-fc-201617-player-ratings/|title=Liverpool FC 2016/17: Overall Season Player Ratings|date=2017-05-22|work=This Is Anfield|access-date=2018-07-08|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thisisanfield.com/2016/11/stats-prove-liverpools-defence-improving-joel-matip-key/|title=Stats prove Liverpool's defence are improving, and that Joel Matip is key|date=2016-11-28|work=This Is Anfield|access-date=2018-07-08|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==== 2017–18 season ==== [[File:Spartak Moscow VS. Liverpool (16).jpg|left|thumb|247x247px|Matip (left) playing for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] during a [[2017–18 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] game against [[FC Spartak Moscow|Spartak Moskva]], 26 September 2017.|alt=]] On 1 October 2017, Matip was criticized for his poor performance against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], being deemed at fault for Newcastle's goal.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/861050/Newcastle-Liverpool-Joel-Matip-Joselu-goal|title=Newcastle vs Liverpool: Jamie Carragher blames Joel Matip for Joselu goal|last=Winter|first=Lewis|date=2017-10-01|work=Express.co.uk|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en}}</ref> On 4 November, Matip scored his first goal of the [[2017–18 Liverpool F.C. season|2017–18 season]], scoring in a 4–1 win over [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] at the [[London Stadium]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/match/22451|title=West Ham v Liverpool, 2017/18 {{!}} Premier League|website=www.premierleague.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref> On 27 January 2018, Matip scored an [[own goal]] in a 2–3 home defeat to [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] in the [[2017–18 FA Cup#Fourth Round Proper|fourth round of the FA Cup]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/42756218|title=Liverpool 2-3 West Bromwich Albion|date=2018|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-07-08|language=en-GB}}</ref> On 31 March, during the match against Crystal Palace, Matip suffered a thigh injury. On 3 April, Liverpool announced that he would have to undergo surgery to fix it, and that he will miss the rest of the season.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/296284-joel-matip-injury-news|title=Liverpool confirm Joel Matip injury|work=Liverpool FC|access-date=2018-06-17}}</ref>
==== 2018–19 season ==== Matip suffered another muscle injury in July 2018 during a tour of the United States,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/tour-2018/308451-joel-matip-injury-update|title=Jürgen Klopp offers Joel Matip injury update|work=Liverpool FC|access-date=2018-07-23}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/tour-2018/308584-joel-matip-injury-update|title=Joel Matip injury update|work=Liverpool FC|access-date=2018-07-23}}</ref> but recovered to be named an unused substitute in a 2–0 away win over [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on 20 August.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45165666|title=Crystal Palace 0-2 Liverpool: James Milner and Sadio Mane score as Reds move to six points|date=2018-08-20|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-08-23|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==International career== Matip was called up on 23 December 2009 by [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]] for the [[2010 Africa Cup of Nations]] but he later declined to take part in the tournament.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.fecafootonline.com/?lng=1&module=media&idrub=96826&idnews=82399 | title = CAN 2010 : La liste des 23 | publisher = fecafootonline.com | date = 22 December 2009 | accessdate = 5 August 2012 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120302151804/http://www.fecafootonline.com/?lng=1&module=media&idrub=96826&idnews=82399 | archivedate = 2 March 2012 | df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.reviersport.de/103801---schalke-matip-fuer-afrika-cup-nominiert.html | title = Matip für Afrika-Cup nominiert | language = German | publisher = reviersport.de | date = 23 December 2009 | accessdate = 5 August 2012}}</ref> It was not yet clear if Matip would represent Cameroon in the future as the [[German Football Association]] still hoped that he might represent his country of birth instead.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11881_5818893,00.html | title = Matip wanted by Germany | publisher = Sky Sports | date = 1 January 2010 | accessdate = 5 August 2012}}</ref>
On 2 March 2010, aged 18, Matip opted to play his international football for Cameroon, after meeting up with the national team ahead of a friendly against [[Italy national football team|Italy]] on 3 March 2010.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/8546027.stm | title = Joel Matip signs for Schalke and decides on Cameroon | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 2 March 2010 | accessdate = 5 August 2012}}</ref> He made his first appearance in the match against Italy and went on to play in the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] for Cameroon.
He was part of the [[Cameroon national football team]] for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] where he played twice and scored against the host team [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]].<ref>[https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/matches/round=255931/match=300186472/report.html Match report]</ref> In January 2017, Matip was selected for the [[2017 Africa Cup of Nations]] but rejected the call-up.<ref>{{cite web|title=Africa Cup of Nations: Liverpool's Joel Matip among seven to snub tournament|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38385694|website=BBC Sport|date=20 December 2016}}</ref>

language = German | publisher = reviersport.de | date = 24 October 2009 | accessdate = 5 August 2012}}</ref> and former [[Cameroon]]ian footballer Jean Matip.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://gesamtschule.mcs-bochum.de/willkommen/schultuete/index.html?tx_reddownloads%5Bfile%5D=17&cHash=7830fbd178 | title = Die Schultüte | language = German | publisher = Matthias-Claudius-Schulen Reserves and Academy|Liverpool]] | years1 = 2018- | clubs1 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] | caps1 = 0 | goals1 = 0 | club-update = 16:56, 23 August 2018 (UTC) }} '''Nathaniel Phillips''' (born 21 March 1997), is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/player/275109/nathaniel-phillips |title=Nathaniel Phillips |publisher=ESPN FC |website=espnfc.com |access-date=2018-10-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181026222938/http://www.espnfc.com/player/275109/nathaniel-phillips# |archive-date=2018-10-26 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2019/clubs/player=150515920/index.html |title=Nathaniel Phillips |publisher=UEFA |website=uefa.com |access-date=2018-10-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181026232521/https://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2019/clubs/player=150515920/index.html# |archive-date=2018-10-26 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/14051/Nathaniel-Phillips/overview |title=Nathaniel Phillips |publisher=Premier League |website=premierleague.com |access-date=2018-10-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181027021634/https://www.premierleague.com/players/14051/Nathaniel-Phillips/overview# |archive-date=2018-10-27 |dead-url=no |df= }}</ref>
==Career== Phillips joined Liverpool ahead of the [[2016–17 Liverpool F.C. season|2016–17 season]] on a free transfer from [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/team/first-team/player/nathaniel-phillips|title=Profile|accessdate=23 August 2018|publisher=Liverpool F.C.|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180806162625/https://www.liverpoolfc.com/team/first-team/player/nathaniel-phillips#|archive-date=2018-08-06|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> He missed a large part of the [[2017–18 Professional U23 Development League|2017–18 season]] due to a back injury. He captains the [[Liverpool F.C. Reserves and Academy#U23s|Liverpool U23]] squad, and was promoted to the first team squad for the [[2018–19 Liverpool F.C. season|2018–19 season]]. He is yet to play in a senior game.

{{About||the blues pianist|Curtis Jones (pianist)|the footballer|Curtis Jones (footballer)|the funk musician|Slave (band)}} {{BLP sources|date=February 2008}} {{Infobox musical artist | image = Cajmere @ afterhours.jpg | name = Curtis Jones | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1967|04|26|}} | birth_place = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] | alias = {{hlist|Cajmere|Green Velvet|Gino Vittori|Geo Vogt|Curan Stone|Half Pint}} | origin = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States | instrument = {{hlist|Synthesizers|vocals}} | genre = {{hlist|[[Techno music|Techno]]|[[House music|house]]|[[Minimal techno|minimal]]}} | years_active = 1991–present | label = {{hlist|Relief|Cajual|Music Man|F-111|[[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]]}} | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|green-velvet.com}} | current_members = }}
'''Curtis Alan Jones''' (born April 26, 1967) is an American singer, songwriter and record producer. His style of house and techno music has been compared to and inspired by the likes of [[Kraftwerk]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Interview With Green Velvet|url=http://thestar.ie/preacher-man-interview-with-green-velvet/|publisher=The Irish Daily Star}}</ref> [[Prince (musician)|Prince]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Green Velvet Interview|url=https://news.beatport.com/chicagos-ageless-unapologetic-raver-green-velvet-remains-defiant-and-unshakable/|website=Beatport|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925094001/https://news.beatport.com/chicagos-ageless-unapologetic-raver-green-velvet-remains-defiant-and-unshakable/|archivedate=2015-09-25|df=}}</ref> [[Gary Numan]], and [[Nitzer Ebb]].
Jones is also known as '''Cajmere''', '''Geo Vogt''', '''Green Velvet''', '''Half Pint''', '''Curan Stone''', and '''Gino Vittori'''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Curtis Jones aliases & discography|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/219-Green-Velvet|website=Discogs.com}}</ref>
==Biography==
===Early years=== Before becoming a professional musician, Jones studied chemical engineering at the University of Illinois. In 1991, he left a Master's program at [[University of California, Berkeley|UC-Berkeley]] to move back to Chicago, releasing his first song ("Coffee Pot" on ClubHouse Records) the same year.<ref name="rough">{{cite book | last = Bidder | first = Sean | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = House: the Rough Guide | publisher = Rough Guides Ltd | date = June 1999 | location = London | pages = 44–46 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = }}</ref> Up until this point, music had been a hobby fueled by cobbling together tracks on his "sixty-buck keyboard, a cheap four-track and a cheap drum machine"{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} set-up while still an undergraduate at the University of Illinois. This DIY method of production was never taken seriously, and when childhood plans to become a doctor were shelved, Jones was firmly committed to a career as a chemical engineer. His father was an occasional DJ and eventually became a budding musician. As time went on, Jones discovered what was his innate love and understanding for house music, a sound that had grown throughout the mid-1980s out of Chicago's deep-rooted house music scene. He played the saxophone at school and had a talent for trying to play with a keyboard but remained largely un-interested in what he saw as his father's passion. It was this cut-up and tacky production style of the early house sound that Jones absorbed and translated{{Citation needed|date=August 2007}} into the ''Underground Goodies'' EP, his first release as Cajmere (the CAJ derived from the artist's initials) <ref>[http://www.deejaybooking.com/greenvelvet DJ Booking biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070220230353/http://www.deejaybooking.com/greenvelvet |date=2007-02-20 }} Accessed 2008-03-18</ref>) put out in 1991 on his own recently started Cajual label.<ref name="rough" /> A year later he had his first massive hit as Cajmere with the house tune "Coffee Pot (It's Time for the Percolator)," which was also released on Cajual and distributed by NYC-based Emotive Records. He then teamed up with Chicago-based vocalist [[Dajae]] for "Brighter Days," which entered #2 on the ''Billboard'' [[Hot Dance Music/Club Play]],<ref name="rough" /> a high-impact and mellower house tune that was released on Cajual and distributed by NYC-based Emotive Records.
===Green Velvet transformation=== Interested in making something totally different from his Cajmere moniker and other work, Curtis created Relief as an offshoot to his Cajual records in 1993. The first Relief release was also his first Green Velvet production, 1993's "Velvet Tracks,"<ref name="rough" /> which came from a name given to him by a girlfriend's father, emerged as the flamboyant, neon-haired electro punk, although in interviews he denied being linked to the Punk lifestyle and fashion, as he was more inspired by the likes of [[David Bowie]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Interview with Green Velvet|url=https://www.trackitdown.net/news/show/100867.html|website=Trackitdown.net}}</ref> and [[Sly and the Family Stone]],<ref name=trustthedj>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090710101125/http://www.trustthedj.com/SKRUFFF/news_article.php?news_id=5931] An interview with Curtis, web archive from 2009</ref> he created mid-1990s hits such as "Preacher Man," on which a [[Moral Majority]]-type of preacher spoke (the Reverend Trotter,<ref>{{Cite web|title=An Interview With Cajmere|url=http://thequietus.com/articles/10599-cajmere-green-velvet-interview|website=The Quietus |author=Melissa Bradshaw |date=7 November 2012 |accessdate=31 October 2015|quote=Green Velvet's 'The Preacher Man', a pumping acid-y techno track which featured Chicago's Reverend Trotter sermonising about young people these days sleeping around, was conceived when Jones got home after a night out and heard Trotter on the radio.}}</ref> not, contrary to popular belief, Reverend Franklin); "Answering Machine," a darkly funny house track consisting of taped messages from an answering machine, including a bad news message from a girlfriend and a noise complaint message from his landlord—all made with Jones's voice; and "Flash," which was a #1 US dance hit in 1995 and was included on many [[disc jockey|DJ]]-mixed compilation albums. After DJing under both of his now infamous monikers, he released his first album, ''[[Constant Chaos]]'', with Belgian Music label Music Man in 1999,<ref name="rough" /> which showed Green Velvet's style of house progress into styles similar to [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] and [[Kraftwerk]], his spoken-word monologues also took a bizarre turn. In ''Abduction'' he spoke about little green men turning up while washing dishes.
===The ''Whatever'' era=== By the time ''Constant Chaos'' was released, Jones had temporarily halted activity on his labels for almost a year. Still DJing as Cajmere he'd narrowed the Green Velvet persona down to live performances only, taking time out to re-group and work out what to do next. During 2000, Jones was briefly signed to [[Warner Bros. Records]]' short-lived F-111 imprint, where he released his second compilation album, the self-titled ''[[Green Velvet (album)|Green Velvet]]'', which contained the double-A-sided single “Flash” backed with “Answering Machine.” During this time he gave Velvet a new hairstyle—from spiked, green foam nodules to yellow mohawk. Next, in 2001, he unleashed his second album, the dark ''[[Whatever (Green Velvet album)|Whatever]]'', which was a step away from his [[Kraftwerk]]-inspired sound (although ''Sleepwalking'' had a similar style) to a darker, more political [[Punk rock|Punk]]-esque style. On the album he tackled such issues as racism (highlighted on the song ''When?''), drug use (highlighted on ''Genedefekt'' and ''La La Land''), alienation (highlighted on ''Sleepwalking''), and being told what to wear and do by “the system” (highlighted on the heavily punk-inspired track ''Gat''). The more punk-oriented songs on the album apparently came from hours spent listening to [[industrial music|industrial]] bands such as [[Nitzer Ebb]] and Liaisons Dangereuses, and lots of "underground American industrial stuff." He released the single ''La La Land'' in 2001, originally designed as a wake-up call for clubbers to the dangers of pill-taking it became one of his most popular tunes. This was followed by ''Genedefekt''. His live act had now became more like a rock band also, with the Curtis playing a [[keytar]], and two other musicians (aptly named Nazuk and Spaceboy) backing him, playing heavily distorted synths. Initially Jones, as both Cajmere and Green Velvet, was receiving more attention in Europe than he did in the USA, playing a [[BBC Radio 1|Radio One]] live session on the [[Jo Whiley]] show and playing a host of festivals.
===Recent projects=== After appearing under a host of different names for his various remixing and side projects, Green Velvet released his third album, ''[[Walk In Love]]'', in 2005. This album had a more [[house music]]-oriented style to it, but the odd Prince- and Punk-sounding tracks still remained, as Curtis actually got a live guitarist to play on "Come Back" and the closing track "Pin-Up Girl" had a similarity to New York-based Electroclash group [[Fischerspooner]]. After ''Walk In Love'', Green Velvet produced and remixed releases for fellow Relief Records artists and himself, and played a host of DJ session live shows in 2006.
After staying quiet in the music scene, Green Velvet revealed in 2006 he had become a [[born-again Christian]] after a serious overdose of a mixture of [[Magic Mushrooms]], [[Marijuana]] and (allegedly) [[gamma-Hydroxybutyric acid|GHB]],<ref name=trustthedj/> and promised to turn his life around after this incident. His latest release, the single "Shake and Pop", is a departure from the recent darker electronica style, as he claims he has found a brighter future since converting. In 2007, he released the online-only track "Love Peace, Not War", a short ditty in response to the United States' war in Iraq.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Green Velvet: All about the love|url=http://inthemix.junkee.com/green-velvet-all-about-the-love/13315 |author=Jack Tregoning |date=21 April 2010 |accessdate=4 January 2018}}</ref>
In 2014, Green Velvet joined forces with [[Claude VonStroke]], another veteran artist who grew up in the Mid-West, to form a side project known as Get Real. With both having a noticeable impact on both the house and techno scenes, many wondered why this duo didn't happen sooner. In reality, the project was by accident. However, it couldn't have turned out better. Their first release came out as an EP on Claude's label, Dirtybird, with the appearance of “Mind Yo Bizness” and “Snuffaluffagus". Claude has stated, “Nobody is trying to steal the spotlight or take over the project which isn’t always the case in a duo. We each represent our style but we make a new style by working together.”<ref>{{cite web|title=Claude VonStroke & Green Velvet are taking Get Real to the next level|url=https://dancingastronaut.com/2015/01/claude-vonstroke-green-velvet-real-deal/}}</ref>

Reserves and Academy|Liverpool]] | years1 = 2016– | clubs1 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] | caps1 = 6 <!-- Premier League appearances only --> | goals1 = 0 <!-- Premier League goals only --> | years2 = 2018 | clubs2 = → [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] (loan) | caps2 = 7 | goals2 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2014 | nationalteam1 = Wales U15 | nationalcaps1 = 2 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2015 | nationalteam2 = Wales U16 | nationalcaps2 = 1 | nationalgoals2 = 3 | nationalyears3 = 2014–2016 | nationalteam3 = [[Wales national under-17 football team|Wales U17]] | nationalcaps3 = 8 | nationalgoals3 = 1 | nationalyears4 = 2016–2018 | nationalteam4 = [[Wales national under-19 football team|Wales U19]] | nationalcaps4 = 4 | nationalgoals4 = 2 | nationalyears5 = 2017– | nationalteam5 = [[Wales national football team|Wales]] | nationalcaps5 = 9 | nationalgoals5 = 1 | club-update = 17:07, 10 January 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 21:00, 20 November 2018 (UTC) }} '''Benjamin Woodburn''' (born 15 October 1999) is a Welsh professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], and for the [[Wales national football team|Wales national team]].
Woodburn became Liverpool's third-youngest player in history upon making his senior debut in November 2016 and the club's youngest-ever goalscorer in his second appearance. He is also Wales' second-youngest-ever goalscorer behind [[Gareth Bale]], having netted on his senior debut at the age of 17 in September 2017.
==Club career==
===Liverpool===
====Early career==== Born in [[Nottingham]], Woodburn was raised in [[Tattenhall]], [[Cheshire]] and played both [[cricket]] and football from a young age.<ref name="LFCprofile">{{Cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/team/first-team/player/ben-woodburn |title=Ben Woodburn |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |accessdate=2 October 2017}}</ref><ref name="seniorcallup">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/mar/16/wales-liverpool-ben-woodburn-call-up-squad-republic-of-ireland|title=Chris Coleman denies trying to tie wonderkid Ben Woodburn to Wales|newspaper=The Guardian|first=Stuart|last=James|date=16 March 2017|accessdate=16 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chesterchronicle.co.uk/sport/who-ben-woodburn-tattenhall-teenager-12250932|first=David|last=Triggs|title=Who is Ben Woodburn? The Tattenhall teenager who became a Liverpool FC record-breaker|newspaper=[[Chester Chronicle]]|date=30 November 2016|accessdate=4 December 2016}}</ref> He joined [[Liverpool F.C. Reserves and Academy|Liverpool's academy]] at under-7 level where he steadily progressed through the youth ranks, leading to former academy director Frank McParland identifying him as one of the brightest prospects at the club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/38154968/who-is-liverpool-record-breaker-ben-woodburn|first=Ben|last=Mundy|title=Who is Liverpool record-breaker Ben Woodburn?|publisher=[[Newsbeat]]|date=30 November 2016|accessdate=4 December 2016}}</ref><ref name="seniorcallup"/> During his schooling, Liverpool agreed to a request from Woodburn's parents that he should stay at home rather than in [[Rainhill]], which was closer to the academy in [[Kirkby]]. In order to facilitate his development, the club arranged for a driver to transport him every day from training back to his home in Tattenhall.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/fa-league-cups/liverpool-vs-leeds-match-report-efl-cup-ben-woodburn-divock-origi-a7446521.html|title=Liverpool vs Leeds match report: Ben Woodburn enjoys night to remember but Garry Monk's men go down fighting|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|first=Simon|last=Hughes|date=30 November 2016|accessdate=30 November 2016}}</ref> When he was 15 years old, Woodburn was fast-tracked from Liverpool's under-16s to the under-18s and his rapid development saw him included in Liverpool's "Futures Group", a programme which afforded the club's most talented young players a weekly opportunity to train with then first-team [[Coach (sport)|coach]], Pep Lijnders.<ref name="youth">{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/who-liverpool-fc-teenager-ben-10801750|title=Who is Liverpool FC teenager Ben Woodburn?|newspaper=[[Liverpool Echo]]|publisher=Trinity Mirror|first=James|last=Pearce|date=28 January 2016|accessdate=26 November 2016}}</ref>
====2016–17 season==== Having impressed first-team [[Manager (association football)|manager]] [[Jürgen Klopp]] during these training sessions, Woodburn was handed his non-competitive debut during the [[2016–17 Premier League|2016–17]] pre-season in a 1–0 win over [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisanfield.com/2016/07/tranmere-rovers-0-1-liverpool-5-things-learned-pre-season-opener/|title=Tranmere Rovers 0–1 Liverpool: 5 things we learned from the pre-season opener|publisher=This is Anfield|first=Ben|last=Twelves|date=8 July 2016|accessdate=26 November 2016}}</ref> He came off the bench in Liverpool's next match to score one and assist another for [[Roberto Firmino]] in a 5–0 [[Exhibition game#Association football|friendly]] win over [[Fleetwood Town F.C.|Fleetwood Town]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.soccerladuma.co.za/news/articles/categories/english-premier-league/club-friendly-fleetwood-town-0-4-liverpool-13-july-2016/233675|title=Ruthless Reds Crush Fleetwood|work=Soccer Laduma|date=13 July 2016|accessdate=26 November 2016}}</ref> Woodburn then, along with [[Kevin Stewart (footballer)|Kevin Stewart]] and fellow academy graduate [[Trent Alexander-Arnold]], signed his first professional contract with Liverpool on 8 November 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/242420-trio-commit-long-term-futures-to-lfc-by-signing-new-deals|title=Trio commit long-term futures to LFC by signing new deals|publisher=Liverpool F.C.|first=James|last=Carroll|date=8 November 2016|accessdate=26 November 2016}}</ref>
He made his senior debut for Liverpool on 26 November, coming on as a 92nd-minute [[substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Georginio Wijnaldum]] in a 2–0 Premier League victory over [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]].<ref name="Soccerbase1617" /> Upon doing so, Woodburn became Liverpool's third-youngest debutant of all time at the age of 17 years and 42 days, and the club's second-youngest-ever in the Premier League, behind [[Jack Robinson (footballer, born 1993)|Jack Robinson]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/ben-woodburn-becomes-third-youngest-12235324|title=Ben Woodburn becomes the third youngest player in Liverpool's history after making debut against Sunderland|newspaper=Liverpool Echo|first=Paul|last=Gorst|date=26 November 2016|accessdate=26 November 2016}}</ref> Three days later, he became Liverpool's [[List of Liverpool F.C. records and statistics|youngest-ever goalscorer]] at the age of 17 years and 45 days when he came off the bench to score in an [[2016–17 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]] quarter-final win over [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]], bettering [[Michael Owen]]'s record by 98 days.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38059968|title=Liverpool 2–0 Leeds United|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Jonathan|last=Jurejko|date=29 November 2016|accessdate=29 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/nov/29/liverpool-leeds-united-efl-cup-quarter-final-match-report|title=Ben Woodburn sets record as Liverpool break Leeds to reach EFL Cup last four|newspaper=The Guardian|first=Andy|last=Hunter|date=29 November 2016|accessdate=29 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="ygs">{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/245135-stats-liverpool-fc-s-youngest-ever-first-team-goalscorers|title=Liverpool FC's youngest ever first-team goalscorers|publisher=Liverpool F.C.|first=James|last=Carroll|date=29 November 2016|accessdate=30 November 2016}}</ref> Following his rapid development at Liverpool, both [[Sky Sports]] and ''[[The Guardian]]'' named Woodburn as one of the top young players to watch in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11661/10706854/ben-woodburn-among-five-premier-league-youngsters-to-watch-in-2017|title=Ben Woodburn among five Premier League youngsters to watch in 2017|publisher=Sky Sports|last1=Bate|last2=Wright|first1=Adam|first2=Nick|date=28 December 2016|accessdate=29 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/dec/28/rising-stars-10-players-watch-2017|title=Rising stars: 10 players to watch in 2017|newspaper=The Guardian|last1=Ames|last2=Miller|first1=Nick|first2=Nick|date=28 December 2016|accessdate=29 December 2016}}</ref>
On 8 January 2017, he became the then-youngest player to represent the club in the [[FA Cup]] when he started in a 0–0 draw with [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.inquirer.net/234430/klopps-decision-field-youngest-ever-side-backfires|title=Klopp's decision to field youngest ever side backfires|newspaper=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=9 January 2017|accessdate=10 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.thisisanfield.com/2019/01/the-club-record-ki-jana-hoever-could-break-klopps-strange-weakness-so-far-in-the-fa-cup/|title=The club record Ki-Jana Hoever could break & Klopp’s strange weakness so far in the FA Cup|publisher=This is Anfield|last=Matchett|first=Karl|date=7 January 2018|accessdate=7 January 2019}}</ref> His first start in the league followed on 4 April in a 2–1 away triumph over [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] which saw him become the third-youngest player to start for Liverpool in the Premier League era behind Owen and [[Jordon Ibe]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/premier-league/firmino-and-coutinho-rescue-liverpool-and-see-off-stoke-for-crucial-win-in-top-four-race-35606539.html|title=Firmino and Coutinho rescue Liverpool and see off Stoke for crucial win in top four race|newspaper=[[Irish Independent]]|first=Carl|last=Markham|date=8 April 2017|accessdate=8 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/OptaJoe/status/850698947232509953|title=3 – At 17 years & 175 days, Ben Woodburn is the 3rd youngest player to start a PL game for @LFC behind Jordon Ibe and Michael Owen. Prospect|publisher=OptaJoe|website=Twitter|date=8 April 2017|accessdate=8 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-za/news/4639/premier-league/2017/04/08/34426342/not-sick-and-tired-any-more-coutinho-and-firmino-rouse|title=Not sick and tired any more! Coutinho and Firmino rouse Liverpool|publisher=Goal.com|last=Staunton|first=Peter|date=8 April 2017|accessdate=13 April 2017}}</ref> The following week he was nominated for the 2017 [[Golden Boy (award)|European Golden Boy]] award, but was beaten by French forward, [[Kylian Mbappé]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisanfield.com/2017/04/ben-woodburn-listed-prestigious-european-award-2017/|title=Ben Woodburn listed for prestigious European award for 2017|publisher=This is Anfield|last=Lusby|first=Jack|date=11 April 2017|accessdate=13 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/oct/23/golden-boy-2017-kylian-mbappe-wins-award|title=Golden Boy 2017: Kylian Mbappé beats Dembélé and Rashford to award|website=Guardian|date=23 October 2017|accessdate=8 February 2018}}</ref> On 9 May, Woodburn won Liverpool's Academy Player of the Season award following a campaign which saw him score eight goals in [[Professional Development League|Premier League 2]] and break into the first team.<ref name=APOTY>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/2017-liverpool-players-awards-live-13010663|title=The 2017 Liverpool Players' Awards – Relive coverage of the end-of-season event at Anfield|newspaper=Liverpool Echo|last=Doyle|first=Ian|date=9 May 2017|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/wales-wonderkid-ben-woodburn-wins-13011933|title=Wales wonderkid Ben Woodburn wins Liverpool FC academy award|website=WalesOnline|last=Mitchelman|first=Ian|date=10 May 2017|accessdate=10 May 2017}}</ref> He was also later nominated for the Premier League 2 Player of the Season award alongside Alexander-Arnold, though the award was ultimately won by [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]]'s [[Oliver McBurnie]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpools-trent-alexander-arnold-ben-13065390|title=Liverpool's Trent Alexander-Arnold and Ben Woodburn up for award – but where's Harry Wilson?|newspaper=Liverpool Echo|last=Doyle|first=Ian|date=20 May 2017|accessdate=20 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/402106|title=McBurnie named PL2 Player of the Season|publisher=Premier League|date=24 May 2017|accessdate=19 June 2017}}</ref>
====2017–18 season==== The following season, Liverpool's academy coach [[Steven Gerrard]] named Woodburn as captain of the under-19 side for the club's [[UEFA Youth League]] campaign, a competition which ran parallel to the season's [[UEFA Champions League]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/steven-gerrard-making-ben-woodburn-13783203|title=Steven Gerrard on making Ben Woodburn his captain|newspaper=Liverpool Echo|last=Pearce|first=James|date=19 October 2017|accessdate=3 November 2017}}</ref> He made just one senior appearance, as a substitute,<ref name="Soccerbase1718" /> during the first half of the season but signed a new long-term deal with Liverpool in October and was named [[BBC]] Wales Young Sportsman of the Year in December.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/who-ben-woodburn-closer-look-14068259|title=Who is Ben Woodburn? A closer look at the Liverpool prospect Sunderland want on loan|website=Chronicle Live|last=Johns|first=Craig|date=5 January 2018|accessdate=8 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ben Woodburn: Liverpool striker signs long-term deal with the club|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/41755705|publisher=BBC Sport|date=25 October 2017|accessdate=24 February 2019}}</ref><ref name=WYSY>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/wales/42053313|title=BBC Wales Sports Personality of the Year 2017: Jonathan Davies wins award|publisher=BBC|date=4 December 2017|accessdate=5 December 2017}}</ref>
Woodburn continued to represent the youth and reserve sides at the start of the second half of the season. On 21 February 2018, he scored once and [[assist (football)|assist]]ed another as Liverpool beat [[Manchester United F.C. Reserves and Academy|Manchester United]]'s U19 side 2–0 to qualify for the quarter finals of the UEFA Youth League.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11095/11260809/liverpool-2-0-manchester-united-ben-woodburn-inspires-reds-in-uefa-youth-league|title=Liverpool 2–0 Manchester United: Ben Woodburn inspires Reds in UEFA Youth League|website=Sky Sports|last=Wilkinson|first=Jack|date=21 February 2018|accessdate=2 March 2017}}</ref> There, the club was eliminated by [[Manchester City F.C. EDS and Academy|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://kwese.espn.com/football/manchester-city/story/3419726/steven-gerrards-liverpool-u19s-knocked-out-of-uefa-youth-league-by-manchester-city|title=Steven Gerrard's Liverpool U19s knocked out of UEFA Youth League by Man City|publisher=ESPN|last=Price|first=Glenn|date=14 March 2018|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref> He made his second and only other senior appearance for the season on 13 May, coming on as a late substitute for [[Mohamed Salah]] in a 4–0 league win over [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton]].<ref name="Soccerbase1718" /> On 1 July, he and club teammates Alexander-Arnold and [[Herbie Kane]] were named on the shortlist for the [[Golden Boy (award)|2018 Golden Boy]] award.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/305647-trent-alexander-arnold-ben-woodburn-herbie-kane-golden-boy-award|title=Liverpool trio nominated for 2018 Golden Boy award|publisher=Liverpool FC|last=Williams|first=Sam|date=1 July 2018|accessdate=2 July 2018}}</ref>
====2018–19 season: Loan to Sheffield United==== On 31 July 2018, Woodburn signed on a season-long [[Loan (sports)|loan]] with [[EFL Championship|Championship]] side, [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/309960-ben-woodburn-sheffield-united-loan|title=Ben Woodburn joins Sheffield United on loan|publisher=Liverpool F.C.|last=Carroll|first=James|date=1 August 2018|accessdate=1 August 2018}}</ref> He made his debut for the club four days later, coming off the bench for [[David McGoldrick]] in a 2–1 loss to Swansea.<ref name="Soccerbase1819" /> His first start followed on 14 August in a League Cup tie against [[Hull City F.C.|Hull City]] where, with the scores level after regulation time, the match progressed to a [[penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]].<ref name="Soccerbase1819" /> Woodburn converted his spot kick but Sheffield United were ultimately defeated after his former Liverpool teammate Kevin Stewart scored the winning penalty for Hull.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.co.uk/sport/football/sheffield-united/match-report-sheffield-united-exit-the-carabao-cup-as-hull-city-progress-on-penalties-1-9301308|title=Match Report: Sheffield United exit the Carabao Cup as Hull City progress on penalties|newspaper=The Star|last=Shield|first=James|date=14 August 2018|accessdate=15 August 2018}}</ref> He struggled for game time during the first half of the season, however, compounded by an ankle injury sustained in December and by the mid-way point of the campaign had only made eight appearances for the club.<ref name="Soccerbase1819" /><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/liverpool-loanee-ben-woodburn-hit-15561377|title=Liverpool loanee Ben Woodburn hit with another setback in stalled season|newspaper=Liverpool Echo|last=Pearce|first=James|date=18 December 2018|accessdate=18 December 2018}}</ref> He was subsequently recalled from his loan by Liverpool.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/liverpool-considering-loan-offers-forward-15657090|title=Liverpool considering loan offers for forward Ben Woodburn after disappointing Sheffield United spell|newspaper=Liverpool Echo|last=Pearce|first=James|date=10 January 2019|accessdate=11 January 2019}}</ref>
Following his return to Anfield, Woodburn was touted for a loan move to [[Hull City F.C.|Hull City]] but a deal failed to materialize before the closing of the transfer window.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/liverpool/ben-woodburn-misses-out-on-liverpool-loan-exit-after-hull-city-talks-break-down-a4054551.html|title=Ben Woodburn misses out on Liverpool loan exit after Hull City talks break down|publisher=The Standard|last=Lynch|first=David|date=31 January 2019|accessdate=1 February 2019}}</ref>
==International career== Prior to making his senior international debut, Woodburn was eligible to represent both Wales, through his maternal grandfather, and [[England national football team|England]].<ref name="WE">{{cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpools-ben-woodburn-welsh-english-12253550|title=What makes English-born Ben Woodburn Welsh? The Liverpool FC star's complicated situation fully explained|website=WalesOnline|first=Chris|last=Wathan|date=30 November 2016|accessdate=30 November 2016}}</ref> During his early teens he attended a training camp with the [[English Schools' Football Association#International teams|England schoolboys' team]] and was later offered an under-16 call-up by England in August 2014. He rejected the call-up and chose to remain in the Wales setup at the time.<ref name="WE"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/mar/27/wilfried-zaha-england-gareth-southgate-ivory-coast|title=Gareth Southgate wanted Wilfried Zaha for England role but was too late|newspaper=The Guardian|first=Daniel|last=Taylor|date=27 March 2017|accessdate=28 March 2017}}</ref> After his club debut with Liverpool in November 2016, it was reported that England remained hopeful of convincing Woodburn to switch his international allegiance despite previously being rebuffed. The possibility was ended in September the following year when he made his senior international debut for Wales in a competitive fixture.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/england-wales-liverpool-ben-woodburn-12249875|title=England hoping Liverpool hero Ben Woodburn will switch international allegiance|newspaper=Liverpool Echo|first=James|last=Pearce|date=29 November 2016|accessdate=30 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/09/02/wales-1-austria-0-liverpools-ben-woodburn-comes-bench-fire-priceless/|title=Wales 1 Austria 0: Liverpool's Ben Woodburn comes off bench to fire priceless debut winner|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|last=Bascombe|first=Chris|date=2 September 2017|accessdate=3 September 2017}}</ref>
===Youth=== Woodburn has played for [[Wales national football team|Wales]] up to U19 level and was first called up to train at one of the nation's regional development centres at [[Dragon Park]] when he was 13.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/ben-woodburn-wales-international-england-10077350|title=Liverpool star Ben Woodburn's 'choice' to play for Wales, NOT England, shows how Welsh football is thriving|newspaper=[[Daily Mirror]]|last=Jones|first=Mark|date=23 March 2017|accessdate=13 May 2017}}</ref> He played for Wales U15s in two games against Poland in March 2014, scored a [[hat-trick]] for the [[Wales national football team|U16 side]] against [[Northern Ireland national under-16 football team|Northern Ireland]] the following year and then captained the [[Wales national under-17 football team|U17]] team against Greece in 2016.<ref name="youth"/><ref name="WE"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faw.cymru/en/news/wales-u16-win-final-development-match/|title=Wales U16 win Final Development Match|publisher=[[Football Association of Wales]]|date=21 April 2015|accessdate=28 March 2017}}</ref> Later that year, he represented the [[Wales national under-19 football team|U19]] side in their [[2016 UEFA European Under-19 Championship qualification|UEFA European Under-19 Championship qualification]] matches and scored a [[2#In sports|brace]] in a 6–2 win over [[Luxembourg national under-19 football team|Luxembourg]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37997564|title=Ben Woodburn: Liverpool youngster inspired by Gareth Bale & Aaron Ramsey|publisher=BBC Sport|date=16 November 2016|accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref>
===Senior=== On 16 March 2017, Woodburn was called up by head coach [[Chris Coleman (footballer)|Chris Coleman]] to the Wales senior team for the first time, aged 17, for the nation's [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification|World Cup qualifier]] against the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]].<ref name="seniorcallup"/> He remained an unused substitute, however, as Wales played out a 0–0 draw in [[Dublin]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vavel.com/en/football/premier-league/liverpool-fc/770023-liverpool-fc-international-round-up-alexander-arnold-nets-a-brace-as-england-u19s-seal-qualification.html|title=Liverpool FC international round-up: Alexander-Arnold nets a brace as England U19s seal qualification|publisher=Vavel|first=Charlie|last=Malam|date=24 March 2017|accessdate=28 March 2017}}</ref> He made his senior debut on 2 September, coming on as a second-half substitute for [[Tom Lawrence]] and scoring a 25-yard strike in a 1–0 win against [[Austria national football team|Austria]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/live/football/40954822 |title=Wales 1–0 Austria |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 September 2017 |accessdate=2 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/sep/02/wales-austria-world-cup-2018-qualifiers-match-report|first=Paul|last=MacInnes|title=Ben Woodburn's debut scorcher gives Wales vital victory against Austria|newspaper=The Guardian|date=2 September 2017|accessdate=2 September 2017}}</ref> In doing so, he became Wales' second-youngest-ever goalscorer behind [[Gareth Bale]] and kept the nation within reach of qualification. Woodburn featured regularly from the bench towards the back end of the qualification campaign as Wales ultimately fell two points short of a [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Second Round|play-off]] spot.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-za/news/i-wont-sleep-tonight-woodburn-elated-with-debut-screamer-for/1pnpw0obxu1rg1fs4kb3lxmje5|title=Liverpool news: Ben Woodburn 'won't sleep' after stunning goal on debut|publisher=Goal.com|last=Dorman|first=Matt|date=3 September 2017|accessdate=3 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/41567439|title=Wales fail to qualify for 2018 World Cup: What next for Chris Coleman's side?|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Pritchard|first=Dafydd|date=10 October 2017|accessdate=6 May 2018}}</ref> He then made his first start on 14 November in a 1–1 [[Exhibition game#Association football|friendly]] draw with [[Panama national football team|Panama]].<ref name="Soccerway" />
