He represented Germany at [[Germany national youth football team|youth level]]. Born in [[Biberach an der Riss|Biberach]], Karius began his career with [[VfB Stuttgart|Stuttgart]] before moving to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in 2009. After two years in Manchester City's youth system, he returned to Germany with [[1. FSV Mainz 05|Mainz 05]]. He established himself as first-choice goalkeeper for the [[Bundesliga]] side before transferring to Liverpool in 2016 for a fee of £4.75 million.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/05/24/liverpool-sign-475m-goalkeeper-loris-karius-from-mainz/|title=Liverpool sign £4.75m goalkeeper Loris Karius from Mainz|last=Bascombe|first=Chris|date=2016-05-24|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}} ==Early life== Karius was born in [[Biberach an der Riss|Biberach]], Baden-Württemberg on 22 June 1993 to Christine and Harald Karius.{{citeweb|url=http://www.schwaebische.de/home_artikel,-_arid,2795603.html|title=15-Jähriger Biberacher hält künftig Robinhos Schüsse|author=Staff writer(s)|website=Schwäbische Zeitung das Onlineportal|language=German|date=8 May 2008|accessdate=7 November 2016}} Harald intended for his son to become a [[motocross]] rider, but Loris' grandfather, Karl, encouraged him to focus on football.{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/1862/premier-league/2016/11/09/29350962/introducing-loris-karius-how-the-goalkeeper-kicked-past-his|title=Introducing Loris Karius: How the goalkeeper kicked past his struggles to become Liverpool’s No.1|first=Melissa|last=Reddy|website=[[Goal (website)|Goal]]|date=10 November 2016|accessdate=16 November 2016}} Karius attended [[Pestalozzi-Gymnasium Biberach]] until his move to England in 2009 where he was then privately tutored.{{citeweb|url=http://www.spox.com/de/sport/fussball/nachwuchs/1103/Artikel/loris-karius-vfb-stuttgart-manchester-city-jerome-boateng.html|title=Der Werdegang von Loris Karius bei Manchester City|author=Staff writer(s)|website=Spox|language=German|date=17 March 2011|accessdate=7 November 2016}} ==Club career== ===Early career=== Karius played for local team SG Mettenberg and [[SSV Ulm 1846]] before joining [[VfB Stuttgart]], where he rose through the youth ranks and appeared for the German under-16 national team against Macedonia in September 2008.{{citeweb|url=http://www.schwaebische.de/mediathek_galid,205691_titel,-Fussballprofi-Loris-Karius-in-der-Heimat-_toid,157.html|title=Fußballprofi Loris Karius in der Heimat|author=Staff writer(s)|website=Schwäbische Zeitung das Onlineportal|language=German|date=27 March 2016|accessdate=7 November 2016}} ===Manchester City=== [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] invited Karius and his family to England after watching him in Germany's under-16 game against Azerbaijan, and completed his signing on 1 July 2009.{{citeweb|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/632981|title=Stuttgart hit out at City over young goalkeeper|author=Staff writer(s)|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|date=26 March 2009|accessdate=7 November 2016}} Karius played for the under-18 and the under-21 Manchester City teams, but failed to make a senior appearance during his time in Manchester.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/04/09/loris-karius-delighted-finally-get-game-former-club-man-city|title=Loris Karius delighted to finally get a game at former club Man City|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=7 June 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/champions-league/loris-karius-out-to-prove-manchester-city-wrong-1.3455598|title=Loris Karius out to prove Manchester City wrong|publisher=The Irish Times|accessdate=7 June 2018}} ===Mainz 05=== [[File:Loris-Karius-2015-07.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Karius with [[1. FSV Mainz 05|Mainz 05]] in 2015]] Manchester City loaned Karius to [[1. FSV Mainz 05|Mainz 05]] in August 2011, where he played for Mainz 05's reserve team, [[1. FSV Mainz 05 II|Mainz 05 II]], in the [[Regionalliga]]. On 11 January 2012, the move was made permanent with Karius committing himself to a two-year deal with an option for a third year that would extend his contract to June 2015.{{citeweb|url=http://www.kicker.de/news/fussball/bundesliga/startseite/563095/artikel_bis-2014_05-bindet-karius.html|title=Bis 2014: 05 bindet Karius|author=Staff writer(s)|publisher=''[[Kicker (sports magazine)|kicker]]''|language=German|date=11 January 2012|accessdate=7 November 2016}} He made his Mainz 05 debut on 1 December 2012 in a [[Bundesliga]] match against [[Hannover 96]] when he was substituted for [[Shawn Parker]] after goalkeeper [[Christian Wetklo]] had been sent off, which, aged 19 years, 5 months and 9 days old, made Karius the youngest goalkeeper ever to play in the Bundesliga.{{citeweb|url=http://www.goal.com/en/match/mainz-05-vs-hannover-96/1300903/lineups|title=Mainz 05 vs Hannover 96 Match Report|author=Staff writer(s)|website=[[Goal (website)|Goal]]|date=1 December 2012|accessdate=7 November 2016}} He made no further appearances in the 2012–13 season, but established himself as first-choice goalkeeper in the 2013–14 season and on 12 January 2015 signed a three-year contract extension.{{citeweb|url=http://www.bundesliga.de/de/liga/news/loris-karius-verlaengert-bei-mainz-05.jsp|title=Loris Karius verlängert beim 1. FSV Mainz 05|author=Staff writer(s)|publisher=[[Bundesliga]]|language=German|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=7 November 2016}}{{citeweb|url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/sport/football/419780/CONFIRMED-Arsenal-target-Loris-Karius-pens-contract-2018 |title=Arsenal target Loris Karius pens contract until 2018|first=Alex|last=Harris|publisher=[[Daily Star (British newspaper)|''Daily Star'']]|date=12 January 2015|accessdate=7 November 2016}} Karius was ever-present in the [[2015–16 1. FSV Mainz 05 season|2015–16 season]], keeping nine clean sheets, saving two penalties and being voted the second-best goalkeeper in the league in a poll of 235 fellow Bundesliga players, ranking behind only [[Manuel Neuer]].{{citeweb|url=http://www.bundesliga.com/en/news/Bundesliga/noblmd32-bundesliga-your-team-of-the-season-goalkeepers.jsp|title=Team of the Season: Neuer sweeps the board in goalkeeper vote|author=Staff writer(s)|publisher=[[Bundesliga]]|date=6 May 2016|accessdate=7 November 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpool-bound-loris-karius-voted-11376318|title=Liverpool-bound Loris Karius voted second-best Bundesliga goalkeeper|first=Kristian|last=Walsh|publisher=''[[Liverpool Echo]]''|date=24 May 2016|accessdate=7 November 2016}} ===Liverpool=== [[File:Liver-SM 2017 (5) (Loris Karius).jpg|thumb|130px|Karius lining up for [[Liverpool F.C|Liverpool]] in 2017]] On 24 May 2016, Karius signed with [[Liverpool F.C|Liverpool]] for a fee of £4.75 million on a five-year deal.{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/222991-liverpool-agree-deal-to-sign-loris-karius |title=Liverpool agree deal to sign Loris Karius |date=24 May 2016 |first=James |last=Carroll |publisher=[[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool Football Club]] |accessdate=24 May 2016}}{{citeweb|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/transfers/loris-karius-signs-liverpool-goalkeeper-transfer-news-a7046946.html|title=Mainz goalkeeper completes £4.7million move after release clause activated|first=Simon|last=Hughes|publisher=''[[The Independent]]''|date=24 May 2016|accessdate=7 November 2016}} He was given the number 1 jersey.{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/222989-liverpool-confirm-loris-karius-squad-number |title=Liverpool confirm Loris Karius squad number |date=24 May 2016 |first=James |last=Carroll |publisher=[[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool Football Club]] |accessdate=24 May 2016}} ==== 2016–17 season ==== He made his debut in a 3–0 [[EFL Cup]] win over [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] on 20 September 2016.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37346111|title=Derby 0–3 Liverpool |author=Staff writer(s)|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=20 September 2016|accessdate=21 September 2016}} He played his first [[Premier League]] match against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]], which ended in a 5–1 victory for the Reds, on 24 September.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37393500 |title=Liverpool 5–1 Hull City |date=24 September 2016 |first=Phil|last=Dawkes|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=7 November 2016}} He kept his first Premier League [[Shutout|clean sheet]] on 17 October in a 0–0 draw with rivals [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/liverpool-loris-karius-de-gea-9072543|title=Liverpool keeper Loris Karius inspired by David De Gea and insists it will take time to produce at a high level|last=Maddock|first=David|date=18 October 2016|accessdate=24 October 2016|website=[[Daily Mirror]]}} On 24 October 2016, [[Jürgen Klopp]] confirmed that Karius was Liverpool's first-choice goalkeeper, ahead of [[Simon Mignolet]].{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/fa-league-cups/liverpool-news-jurgen-klopp-simon-mignolet-efl-cup-vs-spurs-a7378771.html |title=Liverpool news: Jurgen Klopp confirms Simon Mignolet is no longer No 1 as Liverpool prepare for EFL Cup clash |date=24 October 2016 |author=Staff writer(s) |publisher=''[[The Independent]]''|accessdate=7 November 2016}} After two sub-par performances in early December, which included spilling [[Lewis Cook (footballer, born 1997)|Lewis Cook]]’s tame shot into the path of [[Nathan Aké]] to tap home into an empty net to give Bournemouth a 4–3 win, Karius was dropped from the starting eleven. Regarding this decision, Klopp stated he wanted to take Karius "out the firing line," and that "Karius is a young goalkeeper. He will bounce back."{{cite news|title=Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp backs keeper for future success|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38324774|author=Staff writer(s)|accessdate=15 December 2016|publisher=BBC Sport|date=14 December 2016}} ==== 2017–18 season ==== In the 2018 Champions League quarter-final 2nd leg at [[Manchester City]], with the aggregate scoreline at 3–1 to Liverpool Karius was involved in a controversial incident when he failed to clear a cross into the penalty area, punching the ball downward which ricocheted off teammate James Milner and into the path of Man City striker [[Gabriel Jesus]] who scored, only for the linesman to incorrectly give offside.{{cite news |title=Manchester City 1–2 (agg. 1–5) Liverpool: Mo Salah and Roberto Firmino stun Blues to advance to Champions League semi-finals – 5 talking points |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/match-reports/manchester-city-1-2-agg-12338906 |access-date=12 July 2018 |newspaper=[[The Daily Mirror]] |last=Rathborn |first=Jack |date=10 April 2018}} In the Champions League semi-final home leg against [[AS Roma]], with the scoreline at 0–0 Karius let [[Aleksandar Kolarov]]’s shot go through his hands with the ball then hitting the crossbar, before Liverpool went on to win 5–2.{{cite news |title=Liverpool 5–2 Roma: Win unlike any football I've seen before – Lawrenson |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43888382 |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=25 April 2018 |work=[[BBC Sport]] |access-date=13 July 2018 |last=Lawrenson |first=Mark}} In the away game in Rome, Karius was involved in controversy when he came rushing out of his goal and brought down [[Edin Dzeko]] inside the penalty area, but instead of a penalty and red card the linesman gave offside in what ''The Telegraph'' called “an extremely tight call”. Minutes later Karius parried a Roma shot into the path of Dzeko who made the scoreline 2–1 to Roma, before the game finished 4–2 to Roma and 7–6 to Liverpool on aggregate.{{cite news |title=Liverpool ride their luck in Rome but survive to reach eighth European Cup final |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/05/02/roma-vs-liverpool-champions-league-live-score-updates/ |access-date=12 July 2018 |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |last=Burt |first=Jason |date=3 May 2018 |publisher=[[Telegraph Media Group Limited]]}} Karius started for Liverpool against [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] in the [[2018 UEFA Champions League Final]] which Liverpool lost 3–1.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/44258022|title=Real Madrid 3–1 Liverpool|date=2018-05-26|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en-GB}} He was deemed at fault for two of the goals, the first and third; the first after his throw was blocked by [[Karim Benzema]] and deflected into the net, and the second after he mishandled [[Gareth Bale]]'s 40-yard strike.{{cite web |url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpool-stand-loris-karius-despite-14711508 |title=Liverpool will stand by Loris Karius despite Champions League horror show |publisher=Liverpool Echo |author=Ian Doyle |date=27 May 2018 |accessdate=27 May 2018}} After the match, he wept and tearfully apologised to Liverpool fans who remained in the stands.{{cite web |url=https://metro.co.uk/2018/05/26/loris-karius-gives-tearful-apology-liverpool-fans-mistakes-real-madrid-7580859/ |title=Loris Karius gives tearful apology to Liverpool fans after mistakes against Real Madrid |publisher=Metro |author=Chris Dawie |date=26 May 2018 |accessdate=27 May 2018}} He also stated that his mistakes "lost the team the final".{{cite news |date=26 May 2018 |title=Loris Karius apologises to Liverpool for Champions League horror show: 'my mistakes lost us the final' |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/european/loris-karius-liverpool-champions-league-mistakes-real-madrid-final-mohamed-salah-sergio-ramos-a8371136.html |work=The Independent |accessdate=26 May 2018}} After the match, Karius received online [[death threats]], mainly on [[Twitter]], which prompted [[Merseyside Police]] to launch an investigation.{{cite news |date=26 May 2018 |title=Liverpool goalkeeper Loris Karius sent death threats by fans after howlers during Champions League final |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/liverpool-goalkeeper-loris-karius-sent-death-threats-by-fans-after-howlers-during-champions-league-a3849211.html |publisher=Standard.co.uk |accessdate=27 May 2018}}{{cite news |date=26 May 2018 |title=Loris Karius: Liverpool goalkeeper receives death threats after howlers|url=https://www.thesouthafrican.com/loris-karius-liverpool-death-threats/|publisher=The South African |accessdate=27 May 2018}} Five days later, Karius underwent an examination at [[Massachusetts General Hospital]]. Medics concluded he had suffered a concussion from an elbow to his head, reportedly from [[Sergio Ramos]] just minutes before his first mistake. Doctors, however, did not pinpoint the exact moment he was concussed. According to doctor [[Ross Zafonte]], it was possible the concussion affected his performance.{{cite web |last1=Zafonte |first1=Ross |last2=Herget |first2=Lenore |title=Statement regarding Loris Karius From Dr. Ross Zafonte and Lenore Herget, PT, DPT |url=https://www.massgeneral.org/News/newsarticle.aspx?id=6792 |publisher=[[Massachusetts General Hospital]] |accessdate=4 June 2018 |date=4 June 2018}}{{cite news |title=Loris Karius: Liverpool keeper concussed during Champions League final – doctors |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44363648 |accessdate=4 June 2018 |work=[[BBC Sport]] |date=4 June 2018}} Later, on 6 July, at the start of pre season, Klopp stated that Karius was "100% influenced by his concussion", leading to his errors, with Klopp saying "We don't use it as an excuse, we use it as an explanation. For me, it's 100% the explanation [for his performance]. He was influenced by that knock – that is 100%".{{Cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/jurgen-klopp-says-loris-karius-12862355|title=Klopp opens up on Karius Champions League final concussion for the first time|last=Jones|first=Mark|date=2018-07-06|work=mirror|access-date=2018-07-06}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/44735514|title=Loris Karius: Liverpool keeper influenced by Champions League final concussion – Jurgen Klopp|date=2018-07-06|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/306090-jurgen-klopp-loris-karius-concussion|title=Jürgen Klopp speaks on Loris Karius concussion|work=Liverpool FC|access-date=2018-07-06}} ==== 2018–19 season ==== Karius’s handling was back in the spotlight in July 2018 during pre season with Liverpool. In the warm-up to Liverpool’s pre-season opener against [[Chester City F.C.|Chester City]], footage showed Karius spilling the ball into his own net. Against [[Tranmere Rovers]] on 10 July, he fumbled a free-kick which directly led to a goal.{{cite news |title=Klopp rallies behind Karius after pre-season blunder |url=https://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2018/0710/977810-klopp-rallies-behind-karius-after-pre-season-blunder/ |accessdate=23 August 2018 |agency=RTE}} Nine days later Liverpool broke the world transfer fee record for a goalkeeper when they signed [[Alisson (footballer, born 1992)|Alisson]] for an initial fee of €62.5 million (£56m), which could rise to €72 million (£66.8 million) with performance-based bonuses, and relegated Karius to a back up.{{cite web |url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/liverpool-confirm-signing-alisson-becker-14930903 |title=Liverpool confirm signing of Alisson Becker in world record deal |author=Pearce, James |publisher=Liverpool Echo |date=19 July 2018 |access-date=1 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180720022616/https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/liverpool-confirm-signing-alisson-becker-14930903 |archive-date=20 July 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} Against [[Borussia Dortmund]] on 22 July, Karius came rushing out of his box but his scuffed clearance fell straight into the path of [[Maximilian Philipp]] who was unable to put the ball into the empty net from 40 yards. He was deemed at fault for Dortmund’s third goal late on when he parried [[Christian Pulisic]]’s shot from close range directly into the path of [[Jacob Bruun Larsen]], who scored.{{cite news |title=Liverpool fans worry for Loris Karius as he makes a mistake after four minutes against Borussia Dortmund |url= https://metro.co.uk/2018/07/22/liverpool-fans-worry-loris-karius-makes-mistake-four-minutes-borussia-dortmund-7746854/?ito=cbshare |accessdate=23 August 2018 |work=Metro}} ==== Loan to Beşiktaş ==== On 25 August 2018, Karius joined Turkish club [[Beşiktaş J.K.|Beşiktaş]] on a two-year loan move.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45311332|title=Loris Karius: Liverpool goalkeeper joins Turkey's Besiktas on loan|date=2018-08-25|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-08-25|language=en-GB}} ==International career== Karius represented Germany at all youth levels from under-16 onward, but his appearances were limited due to competition from [[Manuel Neuer]], [[Timo Horn]] and [[Marc-André ter Stegen]].{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 2 March 2019}} {| class=wikitable style=text-align:center |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !rowspan=2|Club !rowspan=2|Season !colspan=3|League !colspan=2|National Cup{{efn|Includes [[DFB-Pokal]] and [[FA Cup]]}} !colspan=2|League Cup{{efn|Includes [[EFL Cup]]}} !colspan=2|Europe !colspan=2|Total |- !Division!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |rowspan=4|[[1. He began his career at [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], playing regularly in four [[EFL Championship|Championship]] seasons, before a move to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2012, where he spent three seasons in the Premier League. He joined Liverpool in July 2015 for a fee of £12.5 million. Formerly an international at [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[England national under-21 football team|under-21 level]], Clyne made his senior international debut for [[England national football team|England]] in November 2014. He was selected for [[UEFA Euro 2016]]. ==Club career== ===Crystal Palace=== Clyne was born in [[Stockwell]], London. He made his first-team debut for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in a 3–0 [[EFL Championship|Championship]] win against [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] at [[Selhurst Park]] on 18 October 2008.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7665071.stm |title=Crystal Palace 3–0 Barnsley |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 May 2010 |date=18 October 2008}} He signed a three-year professional contract with the club two days later, with manager [[Neil Warnock]] stating that Clyne "has a bright future in the game".{{cite news |url=http://www.thisiscroydontoday.co.uk/latestsport/Exclusive-Youngster-pens-year-deal/article-412991-detail/article.html |title=Youngster pens three-year deal |publisher=Croydon advertiser |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081024203117/http://www.thisiscroydontoday.co.uk/latestsport/Exclusive-Youngster-pens-year-deal/article-412991-detail/article.html |archivedate=24 October 2008}} His first career goal came on 8 December 2009, when he opened a 4–2 win at [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] in the seventh minute.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8390609.stm "Reading 2–4 Crystal Palace"] BBC Sport. 8 December 2009. Retrieved 4 January 2014. In February 2010 he was offered a move to [[Premier League]] club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]], but rejected it without even entering talks with manager [[Mick McCarthy]].{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11661_5909424,00.html |publisher=Sky Sports |title=Clyne snubs Wolves move |accessdate=19 July 2012 |date=1 February 2010}} In the 2010–11 season, Clyne was the youngest player in the Football League to play every single match of that campaign,{{cite web |title=First Team Profiles: Nathaniel Clyne |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/team/player-profile/nathaniel-clyne/2 |publisher=Southampton F.C. |accessdate=2 October 2014}} and won Crystal Palace's [[Crystal Palace F.C. Player of the Year|Player of the Year]] award.{{cite web |url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2015/may/cpfc-player-of-the-year---the-history/ |title=CPFC Player of the Year – The history |publisher=Crystal Palace F.C. |accessdate=2 October 2014 |date=6 May 2014}} ===Southampton=== [[File:Nathaniel Clyne (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Clyne playing for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2012]] On 19 July 2012, Clyne signed a four-year deal with newly promoted Premier League club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].{{cite web |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10280~2853579,00.html |publisher=Southampton F.C. |title=Saints Secure Clyne Deal |accessdate=1 July 2015 |date=19 July 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120721232533/http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10280~2853579,00.html |archivedate=21 July 2012}}{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18890873 |title=Crystal Palace's Nathaniel Clyne seals Southampton move |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 July 2012 |date=19 July 2012}} He made his debut on 19 August, in a 3–2 defeat against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] at the [[City of Manchester Stadium]].{{cite news |last=Bevan |first=Chris |title=Man City 3–2 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19231354 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2014 |date=19 August 2012}} His first match at [[St Mary's Stadium|St Mary's]] came six days later in a 0–2 defeat by [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]].{{cite news |last=Monaghan |first=Matt |title=Southampton 0–2 Wigan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19304275 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2014 |date=25 August 2012}} He scored his first goal for the club on 22 September, in a 4–1 win at home against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], set up by [[Gastón Ramírez]] with [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21]] coach [[Stuart Pearce]] in attendance at St Mary's.{{cite news |last=Lewis |first=Aimee |title=Southampton 4–1 Aston Villa |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19615244 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2014 |date=22 September 2012}} His second goal for the club came in the [[FA Cup]] third round against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on 4 January 2014, opening an eventual 4–3 home victory with a 25-yard strike past [[Tom Heaton]].{{cite news |last=Cryer |first=Andy |title=Southampton 4–3 Burnley |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25531713 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2014 |date=4 January 2014}} Clyne scored in Southampton's first match of the [[2014–15 Premier League|2014–15 season]], a 2–1 defeat against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Anfield]] on 17 August.{{cite news |last=Ornstein |first=David |title=Liverpool 2–1 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28730043 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2014 |date=17 August 2014}} He scored his second goal of the campaign on 23 September, with a long-range effort which gave Southampton a 2–1 victory at [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in the [[2014–15 Football League Cup|League Cup]] third round.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29216769 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Arsenal 1–2 Southampton |accessdate=23 September 2014 |date=23 September 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.com/capital-one-cup/match/406142/arsenal-southampton/report |publisher=ESPN FC |title=Nathaniel Clyne's goal allows Southampton to see off Arsenal |accessdate=23 September 2014 |date=23 September 2014}} On 24 November, he finished [[Ryan Bertrand]]'s 81st-minute cross to earn a 1–1 draw away to Aston Villa.{{cite news |last=Rostance |first=Tom |title=Aston Villa 1–1 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30077226 |accessdate=24 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 November 2014}} ===Liverpool=== ====2015–2019==== On 1 July 2015, Liverpool confirmed the signing of Clyne from Southampton for £12.5 million on a five-year contract, with his former club, Crystal Palace receiving a payment of £2.5M.{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/187852-liverpool-sign-nathaniel-clyne |title=Liverpool sign Nathaniel Clyne |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |accessdate=1 July 2015}}{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33344772 |title=Nathaniel Clyne: Liverpool sign defender in £12.5m deal |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 July 2015 |accessdate=1 July 2015}} Clyne made his debut in a Liverpool shirt against the True Thai Premier League All Stars in [[Bangkok]] on 14 July as part of the club's pre-season tour.{{cite news |url=http://xtra.liverpoolfc.com/news/debuts-goals-and-a-monsoon-liverpool-players-react-on-twitter-to-bangkok-win |title=Debuts, goals and a monsoon – Liverpool players react on twitter to Bangkok win |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |date=15 July 2015 |accessdate=6 August 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150919023647/http://xtra.liverpoolfc.com/news/debuts-goals-and-a-monsoon-liverpool-players-react-on-twitter-to-bangkok-win |archivedate=19 September 2015 |deadurl=yes}} He made his competitive debut on 10 August in a 1–0 away win against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] in the first match of the [[2015–16 Premier League]] season.{{cite news |title=Stoke 0–1 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33750574 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=10 August 2015 |date=9 August 2015}} On 8 October, Clyne scored his first Liverpool goal in a 1–0 [[2015–16 Football League Cup|League Cup]] fourth round victory over [[AFC Bournemouth]]; the team's first win under [[Jürgen Klopp]].{{cite news |title=Liverpool 1–0 Bournemouth |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34589602 |accessdate=28 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 October 2015}} His first league goal came on 14 February 2016, in a 6–0 win away to Aston Villa.{{cite news |last=Sanghera |first=Mandeep |title=Aston Villa 0–6 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35515112 |accessdate=14 February 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 February 2016}} In March 2016, in Liverpool's first European matches against rivals [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], Clyne won a penalty that [[Daniel Sturridge]] converted in the first leg,{{cite news |last=McNulty |first=Phil |title=Liverpool 2–0 Manchester United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35763810 |accessdate=20 March 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 March 2016}} and conceded a penalty scored by [[Anthony Martial]] in the second, as Liverpool won 3–1 on aggregate in the last 16 of the [[UEFA Europa League]].{{cite news |last=McNulty |first=Phil |title=Manchester United 1–1 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35815538 |accessdate=20 March 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 March 2016}} On 18 May, he played the full 90 minutes in the [[2016 UEFA Europa League Final|final]], a 3–1 loss to [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] in [[Basel]].{{cite news |title=Sevilla make it three in row at Liverpool's expense |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2016/matches/round=2000663/match=2017222/postmatch/report/index.html |accessdate=1 June 2016 |publisher=UEFA |date=18 May 2016}} Prior to the [[2017–18 Premier League|2017–18 season]], Clyne suffered a back injury expected to rule him out until February 2018.{{cite news |last1=Critchley |first1=Mark |title=Liverpool defender Nathaniel Clyne set to miss next three months after operation on back injury |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/nathaniel-clyne-injury-liverpool-fc-news-latest-operation-back-a8052831.html |accessdate=23 January 2018 |work=The Independent |date=13 November 2017}} On 31 March 2018, having missed the entire campaign up to this point, he made his first appearance on the team sheet as an unused substitute in Liverpool's 2–1 league victory away to former club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].{{cite news |last1=Sanders |first1=Emma |title=Crystal Palace 1–2 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/43524303 |accessdate=31 March 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 March 2018}} A week later on 7 April, he made his long-awaited return, keeping a clean sheet in a 0–0 draw against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in a [[Merseyside derby]] clash.{{cite news |last1=Davis |first1=Matt |title=Everton 0–0 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/43602490 |accessdate=7 April 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 April 2018}} ====AFC Bournemouth (loan)==== Clyne joined Premier League club Bournemouth on 4 January 2019 on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] for the remainder of the [[2018–19 A.F.C. Bournemouth season|2018–19 season]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46760201 |title=Nathaniel Clyne: Bournemouth sign Liverpool right-back on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 January 2019 |accessdate=4 January 2019}} He made his debut on 5 January in a 3–1 FA Cup defeat by [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton and Hove Albion]].{{cite web |title=Bournemouth 1 Brighton 3 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46706811 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=6 January 2019 |date=5 January 2019}} ==International career== Clyne was born in England and is of Grenadian descent.{{cite news |last=Tweedale |first=Alistair |title=One in three players at Euro 2016 could play for another country |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/06/09/euro-2016-one-in-three-players-could-play-for-another-country/ |accessdate=17 March 2017 |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=9 June 2016}} On 2 October 2014, Clyne was named in the [[England national football team|England]] squad for the [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying|UEFA Euro 2016 qualifiers]] against [[San Marino national football team|San Marino]] and [[Estonia national football team|Estonia]] later that month.{{cite news |title=England squad: Nathaniel Clyne and Jonjo Shelvey called up |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29460356 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=2 October 2014 |date=2 October 2014}} He was an unused substitute in both matches. Clyne said "My aim, now, is to try to make myself first choice for Euro 2016. That's what I'm going to keep pushing for."{{cite news |title=Nathaniel Clyne wants to make himself first choice right-back for England at Euro 2016 |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/southamptons-nathaniel-clyne-wants-make-4610333 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |accessdate=27 October 2015 |date=11 November 2014}} On 15 November, he made his full international debut in a home qualifier against [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]], playing the full 90 minutes of a 3–1 victory.{{cite news |last=McNulty |first=Phil |title=England 3–1 Slovenia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29964707 |accessdate=15 November 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 November 2014}} Clyne went on to establish himself as first choice right back for England, appearing in five of their last six qualifiers.{{cite news |title=Euro 2016: Who will make England's starting XI in France? (on loan from [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]) | clubnumber = 15 | youthyears1 = 2005–2013 | youthclubs1 = [[Red Star Belgrade]] | years1 = 2013–2016 | clubs1 = [[Red Star Belgrade]] | caps1 = 31 | goals1 = 5 | years2 = 2014 | clubs2 = → [[FK Kolubara|Kolubara]] (loan) | caps2 = 5 | goals2 = 2 | years3 = 2016– | clubs3 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] | caps3 = 8 | goals3 = 0 | clubs4 = → [[Red Star Belgrade]] (loan) | years4 = 2016 | caps4 = 8 | goals4 = 1 | years5 = 2018 | clubs5 = → [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] (loan) | caps5 = 13 | goals5 = 1 | years6 = 2018– | clubs6 = → [[Hertha BSC]] (loan) | caps6 = 14 | goals6 = 3 | nationalyears1 = 2011–2012 | nationalteam1 = [[Serbia national under-16 football team|Serbia U16]] | nationalcaps1 = 4 | nationalgoals1 = 2 | nationalyears2 = 2012 | nationalteam2 = [[Serbia national under-17 football team|Serbia U17]] | nationalcaps2 = 1 | nationalgoals2 = 1 | nationalyears3 = 2014–2015 | nationalteam3 = [[Serbia national under-19 football team|Serbia U19]] | nationalcaps3 = 3 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2015 | nationalteam4 = [[Serbia national under-20 football team|Serbia U20]] | nationalcaps4 = 7 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | nationalyears5 = 2015– | nationalteam5 = [[Serbia national under-21 football team|Serbia U21]] | nationalcaps5 = 13 | nationalgoals5 = 0 | nationalyears6 = 2016– | nationalteam6 = [[Serbia national football team|Serbia]] | nationalcaps6 = 8 | nationalgoals6 = 0 | pcupdate = 23:02, 2 March 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = 9 June 2018 | medaltemplates = {{Medal|Gold|[[FIFA U-20 World Cup]]|[[2015 FIFA U-20 World Cup|2015]]}} }} '''Marko Grujić''' ({{lang-sr-Cyrl|Марко Грујић}}, {{IPA-sh|mâːrko ɡrûːjitɕ|pron}}; born 13 April 1996) is a Serbian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[Hertha BSC]] on loan from [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], and the [[Serbia national football team|Serbia national team]]. A native of [[Belgrade]], Grujić started his career with his hometown club [[Red Star Belgrade]], progressing through their [[youth system]] to the [[first team]] squad. He made his professional debut in 2013, and won the [[Serbian SuperLiga|SuperLiga]] title in his final season with Red Star before completing a £5.1 million move to Liverpool. Grujić is a Serbian international, and represented Serbia at every youth level from under-16 upwards before making his full international debut in May 2016. He was part of the [[Serbia national under-20 football team|Serbian side]] which won the [[2015 FIFA U-20 World Cup|2015 U-20 World Cup]]. ==Club career== ===Red Star Belgrade=== Grujić was born in [[Belgrade]], [[FR Yugoslavia]] (now [[Serbia]]) and is a product of [[Red Star Belgrade]], where he went through the youth program, passed all categories and was the captain of his generation. He made his professional debut for Red Star on 26 May 2013, in a [[Serbian SuperLiga]] match versus [[FK Vojvodina|Vojvodina]].{{cite web |url=http://www.crvenazvezdafk.com/vesti/izvestaji/7369/Vojvodina+-+Crvena+zvezda+3%3A0+(1%3A0).html|script-title=sr:Војводина – Црвена звезда 3:0 (1:0)|website=Red Star Belgrade official website|language=Serbian|date=26 May 2013|accessdate=3 October 2014}} On 17 May 2015, Grujić signed a three-year contract with Red Star to last until 2018.[http://www.rtv.rs/sr_lat/sport/fudbal/grujic-i-jovic-do-2018.-u-zvezdi_600503.html Grujić and Jovic by 2018 in Zvezda] Radio Televizija Vojvodine: ''Grujić i Jović do 2018. u Zvezdi'' {{sr icon}} 17 May 2015 Grujić scored his first senior goal on 26 September 2015 against [[FK Novi Pazar|Novi Pazar]] in a 2–0 victory; he also assisted [[Aleksandar Katai]] for the second goal.{{citeweb|url=https://www.onefootball.com/en/match/fk-red-star-belgrade-vs-fk-novi-pazar-overview-123-444846?period=FullTime&variable=g2|title=Red Star vs Novi Pazar report|publisher=onefootball.com}} Grujić was a part of an unprecedented run of Red Star victories, as the club set a new record for the number of consecutive victories (19), ending the first half of the season without defeat.{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.us/blog/espn-fc-united-blog/68/post/2758612/miodrag-bozovic-is-breaking-records-at-red-star-belgrade|author=Michael Yokhin|title=ESPN: ''Miodrag 'The Count' Bozovic breaking records at Red Star Belgrade''|date=15 December 2015|accessdate=24 February 2016}} ===Liverpool=== Throughout autumn, Grujić was scouted by a number of high-profile European teams, including [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], [[Internazionale]], [[Juventus]], [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], and [[A.C. Milan|Milan]]. [[List of Liverpool F.C. managers|Liverpool manager]] [[Jürgen Klopp]] called Grujić personally to convince him to switch to [[Anfield]], but initially Grujić's father was against his son moving to Liverpool.{{cite web|url=http://www.kurir.rs/sport/fudbal/terzicu-ne-diraj-mi-sina-clanak-2069371|title=OTAC MARKA GRUJIĆA EKSKLUZIVNO ZA KURIR: Terziću, ne diraj mi sina|author=Aleksandar Radonić|language=Serbian|date=23 December 2015|accessdate=24 February 2016}} Klopp's assistant, [[Željko Buvač]], flew to Belgrade to speak with Grujić and on 6 January 2016, it was confirmed that Grujić completed his move to [[Premier League]] side [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], signing a five-year deal for a reported fee of £5.1 million.{{cite web|last1=Bell|first1=Tom|title=Marko Grujic confirmed as Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp's first signing|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/2780433/marko-grujic-confirmed-as-liverpool-player|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|accessdate=12 January 2016|date=6 January 2016}}{{cite news|title=Marko Grujic: Liverpool sign Red Star Belgrade midfielder|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/35244115|accessdate=6 January 2016|publisher=BBC Sport}} Upon joining, Grujić hailed Klopp for convincing him to join and told the press, "I would choose Liverpool over [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] and [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]]."{{Cite web|title = Marko Grujic reveals his Liverpool role, hints at Lazar Markovic's future – This Is Anfield|url = http://www.thisisanfield.com/2016/02/marko-grujic-reveals-his-liverpool-role-hints-at-markovic-future/|website = This Is Anfield|access-date = 24 February 2016|language = en-GB|first = Jack|last = Lusby}} He was immediately loaned back to Red Star until the end of the season for a fee of £740,000, and won the [[Serbian SuperLiga|SuperLiga]] with Red Star while on loan. Grujić finished the season with 29 appearances, 6 goals, 7 assists and was voted into the SuperLiga Team of the Year for his contribution to Red Star's unbeaten season. On 20 August 2016, Grujić made his [[Premier League]] debut for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in a 2–0 loss against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]], coming on in the place of [[Adam Lallana]] in the 78th minute.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37067882|title=Burnley 2–0 Liverpool|last=Bevan|first=Chris|date=20 August 2016|website=BBC.com|publisher=[[BBC]]|access-date=21 August 2016}} ====Loan to Cardiff City==== On 17 January 2018, Grujić joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] side [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on loan for the remainder of the 2017–18 season.{{cite web |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/liverpool-fc-star-marko-grujic-14167521 |title=Liverpool FC star Marko Grujic signs for Cardiff City and describes it as 'breakthrough moment' of his career |publisher=WalesOnline |author=Tom Coleman |date=17 January 2018 |accessdate=17 January 2018}} He made his debut for the club three days later, playing in a 0–0 draw with [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]].{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42671933 |title=Sheffield Wednesday 0–0 Cardiff City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 January 2018 |accessdate=20 January 2018}} Grujić's first goal for Cardiff came in a 2–1 home victory over [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] on 6 March 2018, scoring from range just after the start of the second half.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43206633 |title=Cardiff City 2–1 Barnsley |publisher=BBC Sport |author=Dafydd Pritchard |date=6 March 2018 |accessdate=15 March 2018}}{{cite web|title=Marko Grujic|url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/13985/Marko-Grujic/overview|publisher=Premier League|accessdate=31 January 2017}} ====Loan to Hertha BSC==== On 19 August 2018, Grujić joined [[Bundesliga]] club [[Hertha BSC]] on a one-year loan.{{Cite web|title=Marko Grujic kommt aus Liverpool|trans-title=Marko Grujić joins from Liverpool|date=19 August 2018|accessdate=19 August 2018|publisher=[[Hertha BSC]]|url=https://www.herthabsc.de/de/intern/verpflichtung-marko-grujic/page/14925--17-17-.html}} He scored his first goal for the club on 8 December, netting the only goal in a 1–0 win over [[Eintracht Frankfurt]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bundesliga.com/en/news/Bundesliga/hertha-berlin-eintracht-frankfurt-live-line-ups-stats-luka-jovic-rebic-ibisevic-fantasy-518406.jsp|title=Marko Grujic wins Hertha Berlin all three points against Eintracht Frankfurt|publisher=Bundesliga|date=8 December 2018|accessdate=9 December 2018}} Hertha coach [[Pal Dardai]] hailed Grujić as "by far the best midfielder at Hertha Berlin in 20 years".{{cite news|title=Marko Grujic "by far the best midfielder at Hertha Berlin in 20 years" – Pal Dardai |date=10 December 2018|accessdate=10 December 2018|publisher=Bundesliga|url=https://www.bundesliga.com/en/news/Bundesliga/liverpool-s-marko-grujic-by-far-the-best-midfielder-hertha-berlin-dardai-518902.jsp}} ==International career== Grujić represented Serbia at all youth levels from under-16 to under-21, and was a member of the Serbia squad that won the [[2015 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] in [[New Zealand]].{{citeweb|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11669/10107776/who-is-marko-grujic-we-profile-the-red-star-belgrade-youngster|title=Who is Marko Grujic? We profile Liverpool signing|publisher=skysports.com}} In May 2016, Grujić made his full international debut for the [[Serbia national football team|Serbia national team]] after coming on in place of [[Nemanja Matić]] in a 2–1 win against [[Cyprus national football team|Cyprus]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fss.rs/index.php?id=2021&aid=10348|title=Фудбалски савез Србије – званична веб презентација|website=www.fss.rs}} In May 2018 he was named in Serbia's preliminary squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] in Russia.{{cite news |url=http://www.fss.rs/index.php?id=2021&aid=13898 |title=Један тим, срцем свим – Младен Крстајић одабрао |trans-title=One team, with all their hearts – Mladen Krstajić selects |website=FSS.rs |publisher=[[Football Association of Serbia]] |date=24 May 2018 |access-date=24 May 2018 |language=Serbian}} In June 2018 he was selected in Serbia's squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]],{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/44083365 | title = World Cup 2018: All the confirmed squads for this summer's finals in Russia | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 4 June 2018 | accessdate = 25 June 2018}} but he failed to make any appearances there. ==Style of play== Standing at 6-foot-3-inches (1.91 m), Grujić has been described as "tall, rangy, comfortable on the ball and with a good range of passing" and dubbed the "new Matić" because of his likeness in both appearance and position to fellow Serbian defensive midfielder [[Nemanja Matić]]. ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|end of Ings: Summary |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=8 January 2019}} | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | currentclub = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]]
(on loan from [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]) | clubnumber = 9 | youthyears1 = {{0|0000}}–2009 | youthclubs1 = [[AFC Bournemouth]] | years1 = 2009–2011 | clubs1 = [[AFC Bournemouth]] | caps1 = 27 | goals1 = 7 | years2 = 2010 | clubs2 = → [[Dorchester Town F.C.|Dorchester Town]] (loan) | caps2 = 9 | goals2 = 4 | years3 = 2011–2015 | clubs3 = [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] | caps3 = 122 | goals3 = 38 | years4 = 2015– | clubs4 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] | caps4 = 14 | goals4 = 3 | years5 = 2018– | clubs5 = → [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] (loan) | caps5 = 18 | goals5 = 7 | nationalyears1 = 2013–2015 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps1 = 13 | nationalgoals1 = 4 | nationalyears2 = 2015– | nationalteam2 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps2 = 1 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | club-update = 09:07, 3 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 23:58, 8 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Daniel William John Ings''' (born 23 July 1992) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] from fellow {{English football updater|Liverpoo}} club [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], and the [[England national football team|England national team]]. Ings started his career in the youth team of [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] but was released as a schoolboy. He subsequently joined [[AFC Bournemouth]], progressing through their youth system, while also spending time at [[Dorchester Town F.C.|Dorchester Town]] on loan. In 2011 Ings joined [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] with whom he won the [[2013–14 Football League Championship|2013–14 Championship]] Player of the Year, and helped them achieve promotion to the Premier League. Following Burnley's relegation, and the expiry of his contract with the club, Ings moved to Liverpool in the summer of 2015, but his first season at [[Anfield]] was ended after two months due to injury. His second season with Liverpool was also mired by injury, with Ings only making two League Cup appearances throughout the 2016–17 season. Ings joined Southampton on loan in August 2018, with an obligation to buy at the end of the season. Formerly an [[England national under-21 football team|under-21 international]], Ings made his senior debut for England in October 2015. ==Club career== ===AFC Bournemouth=== Ings was born in [[Winchester]], Hampshire and grew up in [[Netley]], Hampshire. As a child he attended Netley Abbey Primary School and [[Hamble School|Hamble Community Sports College]]. Ings dreamed of playing for local club Southampton, but was rejected for being too small. He signed for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] from Netley Central Sports, before being released as a school boy.{{cite news |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/9141445.Cherries__Boss_Lee_offers_Ings_brand_new_contract/ |newspaper=Southern Daily Echo |location=Southampton |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=Cherries: Boss Lee offers Ings brand new contract |date=15 July 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} After his release, Ings played for [[Southampton|Itchen Tyro]]. He subsequently signed a two-year apprentice contract with [[AFC Bournemouth]] in May 2008, having progressed through the club's Centre of Excellence while he was still at secondary school at Hamble Community Sports College.{{cite news |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/2268488.new_intake_for_coach_joe/ |newspaper=Southern Daily Echo |location=Southampton |first=Ian |last=Wadley |title=New intake for coach Joe |date=14 May 2008 |accessdate=16 October 2009}} He had also previously had experience playing for the reserve team. He made his professional debut for Bournemouth on 6 October 2009, in a 2–1 away defeat to [[Northampton Town F.C.|Northampton Town]] in the [[EFL Trophy|Football League Trophy]], replacing [[Jason Tindall]] in the second half as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8284875.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Northampton 2–1 Bournemouth |date=6 October 2009 |accessdate=16 October 2009}} His second season in the youth team was blighted by a long-term abdominal injury, which restricted his playing time.{{cite news |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/8828804.Cherries__Hot_shot_Ings_can_only_get_better/ |newspaper=Southern Daily Echo |location=Southampton |first=Ian |last=Wadley |title=Cherries: Hot-shot Ings can only get better |date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He remained with the youth team until the summer of 2010, when he signed a short-term three-month contract.{{cite news |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/8711429.Cherries__Howe_has_high_hopes_for_star_Ings/?action=complain&cid=8964719 |newspaper=Southern Daily Echo |location=Southampton |first=Ian |last=Wadley |title=Cherries: Howe has high hopes for star Ings |date=1 December 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He extended his contract in September 2010, until the end of the 2010–11 campaign. In September 2010, he was sent on an initial one-month [[Loan (sports)|loan]] to [[National League South|Conference South]] club [[Dorchester Town F.C.|Dorchester Town]].{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/news/2010/september/11-1.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |first=Adan |last=Summers |title=Ings and out for Magpies |date=11 September 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420101900/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/news/2010/september/11-1.shtml |archivedate=20 April 2013}} His debut for the Magpies came on 11 September 2010, scoring the equaliser in a 2–1 home defeat to [[Ebbsfleet United F.C.|Ebbsfleet United]].{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/ebbsfleet-h-bsbs.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |first=Ky |last=Capel |title=Ebbing away |date=11 September 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420043611/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/ebbsfleet-h-bsbs.shtml |archivedate=20 April 2013}} His second goal for Dorchester came on 24 September, scoring a penalty in a 4–1 win over [[Mangotsfield United F.C.|Mangotsfield United]] in the [[FA Cup]].{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/mangotsfield-a-fac.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |title=Mangoes crushed by Magpies |date=25 September 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420094120/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/mangotsfield-a-fac.shtml |archivedate=20 April 2013}} On 6 October, his loan was extended for a further month.{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/news/2010/october/06-1.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |first=Ky |last=Capel |title=Loanee Danny extends Magpies stay |date=6 October 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420024801/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/news/2010/october/06-1.shtml |archivedate=20 April 2013}} His next goal came in a 4–1 defeat to [[Havant & Waterlooville F.C.|Havant & Waterlooville]] as the Magpies were knocked out of the FA Cup.{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/havant-a-fac.shtml |publisher=Dorchester Town F.C. |first=Ky |last=Capel |title=Magpies' cup dream is over |date=9 October 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420075356/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/season/201011/reports/havant-a-fac.shtml |archivedate=20 April 2013}} On 16 October, he scored the second in a 2–0 league win over [[Lewes F.C.|Lewes]], after coming on as a late substitute for Giuseppe Sole.{{cite web Town F.C. |first=Ky |last=Capel |title=Moss earns treble for Magpies |date=30 October 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 for Magpies |date=12 November 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420002514/http://www.dorchestertownfc.co.uk/news/2010/november/12-1.shtml |archivedate=20 April lasted until 2012.{{cite news |url=http://www.bournemouthecho.co.uk/sport/8711361.Cherries__Ings_signs_contract_extension/ |newspaper=Southern Daily Echo |location=Southampton |first=Neil |last=Perrett |title=Cherries: Ings signs contract extension |date=30 November 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He made his league debut and first start for Bournemouth on 28 December 2010, in a 2–0 away defeat to [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] in [[EFL League One|League One]], where he was substituted off in the first half for [[Steve Fletcher]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9304980.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=MK Dons 2–0 Bournemouth |date=28 December 2010 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He started to become a first-team regular and scored his first professional goal against [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] on 1 February 2011, in a 3–2 win at [[Dean Court]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9377131.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Bournemouth 3–2 Swindon |date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} His form saw him rewarded with a new contract extension, lasting until 2013. On 26 February 2011, he scored a header to equalise in 2–1 win away at [[Dagenham & Redbridge F.C.|Dagenham & Redbridge]] in the league.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9401900.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Dag & Red 1–2 Bournemouth |date=26 February 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} On 1 April he added to his tally with a goal against [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] in a 3–3 draw.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/9436462.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Peterborough 3–3 Bournemouth |date=1 April 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He went through a rich vein of goalscoring from in April, scoring four goals in three matches. He scored an overhead kick to equalise in the last minute against [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]], however, the Cherries went on to lose the match 2–1.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/12945348 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Bournemouth 1–2 Tranmere |date=9 April 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He also scored in a 2–0 away victory over [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/13022988 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Notts County 0–2 Bournemouth |date=16 April 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He scored his first brace in a 2–2 draw with [[Yeovil Town F.C.|Yeovil Town]], including one penalty.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/13102925 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Yeovil 2–2 Bournemouth |date=23 April 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} His final goal for Bournemouth came in the last match of the season, in the play-off semi-final defeat to [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]], as Bournemouth were knocked out on penalties.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/13356811 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Huddersfield 3–3 Bournemouth |date=18 May 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} In the summer of 2011, he was linked with reported moves away from Bournemouth with [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]], [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] and [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]]. [[Premier League]] club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] also had a £400,000 bid rejected by the club. In July 2011, he was rewarded with his fifth contract in twelve months, improving his deal to be one of the top earners at the club. He remained at the club through pre-season and started in the first match of the season in a 3–0 away defeat to [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]]. It proved to be his final appearance for the club.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14351895 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Charlton 3–0 Bournemouth |date=6 August 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} ===Burnley=== [[File:Danny Ings.jpg|thumb|upright|Ings playing for [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in 2012]] On 15 August 2011, Ings signed for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] for an undisclosed fee believed to be in the region of £1 million, on a four-year contract.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/burnley/9564859.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Burnley sign Bournemouth striker Danny Ings |date=15 August 2011 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He rejoined former Bournemouth manager [[Eddie Howe]] who had made the same move eight months earlier. He made his debut on 14 February 2012, in a 2–0 win over [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] at [[Turf Moor]], where he came on as a late substitute for [[Charlie Austin]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/burnley/9564859.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Burnley 2–0 Barnsley |date=14 February 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} His first start came a month later on 10 March 2012, in a 1–1 home draw with [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in the league.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17243698 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Burnley 1–1 Crystal Palace |date=10 March 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} His first goal for Burnley came on 31 March, in a 5–1 win against [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] at [[Fratton Park]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17496929 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Portsmouth 1–5 Burnley |date=31 March 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} His second goal came in the following match, where he scored the equaliser in a 3–1 defeat to [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17520522 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Burnley 1–3 Birmingham |date=3 April 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He scored his third goal of the season in the final match of the season, a 30-yard strike in a 1–1 home draw with [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17795497 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Burnley 1–1 Bristol City |date=28 April 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} He started the [[2012–13 Burnley F.C. season|2012–13]] season as a first choice regular in pre-season following the sale of striker [[Jay Rodriguez]] to Southampton. He scored in friendly wins over [[Altrincham F.C.|Altrincham]] and [[Bury F.C.|Bury]].{{cite news |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/9208461.Howe_blow_as_Ings_needs_knee_surgery/ |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |first=Dan |last=Black |title=Photos: Altrincham 1, Burnley 4 |date=23 July 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0,,10413~2859646,00.html |title=Bury 0 Burnley 1 |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=14 August 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120827083518/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0%2C%2C10413~2859646%2C00.html |archivedate=27 August 2012}} He suffered another serious knee injury in the final pre-season match, a 3–1 defeat to [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]]. He tore the knee cartilage in the opposite knee to the previous season which resulted in surgery, keeping him out of action for up to six months.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19242581 |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Burnley's Danny Ings faces up six months out with knee injury |date=13 August 2012 |accessdate=14 September 2012}} Following the departure of top-scorer Charlie Austin to [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]], Ings became the main striker ahead of the [[2013–14 Burnley F.C. season|2013–14 season]].{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23533841 |title=Charlie Austin: QPR sign Burnley striker for undisclosed fee |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 August 2013 |accessdate=1 August 2013}} He put together a string of impressive performances in the Clarets' pre-season campaign and scored two goals in the opening three league matches as well as a goal in the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] against [[York City F.C.|York City]].{{cite news |title=York 0–4 Burnley |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/23499462 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=8 July 2015 |date=6 August 2013}} For his continued good start to the season Ings was named the [[EFL Championship Player of the Month|Championship Player of the Month]] for October.{{cite web |title=Ings named Player of the Month |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/championship/news/20131108/ings-named-player-of-the-month_2293322_3528162 |publisher=The Football League |date=8 November 2013 2014, Ings won [[Football League Awards#2014 Awards|Championship Player of the Year]] at the [[Football League Awards]], ahead of the two other nominees: Leeds United striker [[Ross McCormack]] and Leicester City midfielder [[Danny Drinkwater]].{{cite web |title=Danny Ings named Sky Bet Championship Player of the Year |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/news/article/danny-ings-named-sky-bet-championship-player-of-the-year-1872482.aspx |publisher=The Football League |date=17 March 2014 2015}} He ended the [[2013–14 Football League Championship|2013–14 Championship]] season with 22 goals as Burnley finished second and gained promotion to the Premier League.{{Cite news |url=http://talksport.com/football/exclusive-ings-burnley-premier-league-and-his-england-hopes-140814107747 |title=Exclusive – Ings on Burnley in the Premier League and his England hopes |accessdate=1 June 2015 |work=TalkSport}} On 19 August 2014, Ings made his Premier League debut in a 3–1 loss to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at Turf Moor.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/gallery/2014/aug/18/premier-league-burnley-chelsea-gallery-pictures |title=Premier League: Burnley v Chelsea – In pictures |date=19 August 2014 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London}} His first Premier League goal came in a 1–3 defeat to [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 26 October.{{cite news United and [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]], and defeat Queens Park Rangers.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/31124671 |title=Man Utd 3–1 Burnley |date=11 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150525131020/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/team/player-profile/danny-ings/10 |archivedate=25 May 2015}} ===Liverpool=== On 8 June 2015, Liverpool announced that they had agreed on personal terms with Ings, subject to a medical,{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/186426-reds-agree-deal-to-sign-danny-ings |title=Reds agree deal to sign Danny Ings |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |date=8 June 2015 |accessdate=8 June 2015}} as well as a developmental fee due to Burnley for players under 24, to be negotiated between two clubs or determined by a tribunal.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/transfers/danny-ings-to-liverpool-reds-may-have-to-pay-record-8m-tribunal-fee-to-secure-free-agent-10284244.html |title=Danny Ings to Liverpool: Reds may have to pay record £8m tribunal fee to secure free agent |date=29 May 2015 |newspaper=The Independent |location=London |first=David |last=Hughes |accessdate=8 June 2015}} Under tribunal the fee would be decided by the [[Professional Football Compensation Committee]].{{cite web |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/regulations/20100801/appendix-5_2293633_2128224 |title=Archived copy |publisher=The Football League |accessdate=4 August 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512091251/http://www.football-league.co.uk/regulations/20100801/appendix-5_2293633_2128224 |archivedate=12 May 2011}} On 28 April 2016, the saga was finally settled. Liverpool would pay Burnley a record fee for a tribunal hearing: £6.5 million up front, with an extra £1.5 million in player performance-related bonuses. Burnley will also receive 20% of any future fee should Liverpool sell the striker.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/apr/28/liverpool-burnley-danny-ings-tribunal-record |title=Liverpool must pay record £8m to Burnley for Danny Ings, tribunal rules |first=Andy |last=Hunter |date=28 April 2016 |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London}} Ings made his competitive debut on 29 August 2015 in a 3–0 defeat against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham]] at Anfield.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34025305 |title=Liverpool 0–3 West Ham |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 August 2015 |accessdate=30 August 2015}} He made his European debut for the club on 17 September in the [[UEFA Europa League]] group stage match against [[Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]], as a substitute for [[Divock Origi]] in a 1–1 draw.{{cite news |title=Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers buoyed by young team |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34286275 |accessdate=18 September 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport}} Three days later, he replaced [[Christian Benteke]] at half time and within three minutes scored his first Liverpool goal in a 1–1 draw against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].{{cite web |last1=Jennings |first1=Patrick |title=Liverpool 1–1 Norwich City |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34236959 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=21 September 2015 |date=20 September 2015}} On 4 October 2015, he opened a draw of the same score against Everton in the [[Merseyside derby]].{{cite news |title=Everton 1–1 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34372497 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=5 October 2015 |date=4 October 2015}} On 15 October 2015, in his first training session under new manager [[Jürgen Klopp]], Ings suffered an [[anterior cruciate ligament injury]] in his left knee and was ruled out for the remainder of the season.{{cite news |title=Danny Ings: Liverpool striker out for season with knee injury |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34542231 |accessdate=15 October 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 October 2015}} However, Ings returned sooner than anticipated, making a substitute appearance in the final match of the season, a 1–1 draw away to West Bromwich Albion.{{cite web |last1=Sport |first1=Mike Henson BBC |title=West Bromwich Albion 1–1 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36240499 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=15 May 2016}} Ings began the 2016–17 season playing in the reserves to help regain fitness. On 25 October 2016, Ings sustained damage to his right knee in a League Cup match against Tottenham Hotspur that would require another spell on the sidelines of up to 9 months.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37845825 |title=Danny Ings: Liverpool striker to miss rest of the season because of injury |date=2 November 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}} He successfully underwent surgery to repair the damage to his knee and began rehabilitation at [[Melwood]] on 9 November.{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/242599-danny-ings-returns-to-melwood-to-begin-rehab |title=Danny Ings returns to Melwood to begin rehab |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |last=Shaw |first=Chris |date=9 November 2016 |accessdate=9 November 2016}} On 19 September 2017, Ings made his first appearance in 11 months since the injury when he came on as a second-half substitute in the 2–0 defeat to [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] in the [[2017–18 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/sep/19/leicester-city-liverpool-carabao-cup-match-report |title=Islam Slimani strike seals Leicester win as Liverpool crash out of Carabao Cup |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=20 September 2017 |accessdate=20 September 2017}} On 21 April 2018, he scored his first goal after his return from injury in a 2–2 draw with West Brom. This was his first goal since 2015 and also his first goal under Jürgen Klopp.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/43762952 |title=West Brom facing relegation despite fightback against Liverpool |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 April 2018 |accessdate=21 April 2018}} ===Southampton=== [[File:Danny Ings 2018.jpg|thumb|upright|Ings playing for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2018]] After struggling playing time in the 2017–18 season due to the form of attackers [[Roberto Firmino]], [[Mohamed Salah]], and [[Sadio Mané]], Ings requested a move away from Liverpool in the summer of 2018. Ings was a popular figure in the dressing room and Jurgen Klopp was reluctant to let him leave in spite of his limited appearances in the previous season.{{cite news |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/danny-ings-interview-at-liverpool-i-would-go-home-sit-with-my-dogs-and-feel-upset-i-moved-to-southampton-to-be-happy-tc2d89g8p |title=Danny Ings interview: At Liverpool I would go home, sit with my dogs and feel upset. I moved to Southampton to be happy |first=Paul |last=Joyce |newspaper=The Times |location=London |date=1 September 2018 |accessdate=16 December 2018}} Ings joined Premier League club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 9 August 2018 on an initial loan until the end of the season, which would become permanent on 1 July 2019,{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45137409 |title=Transfer news: Liverpool's Danny Ings joins Southampton on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 August 2018 |accessdate=9 August 2018}} for a reported fee of £18 million, plus a possible further £2 million based on appearances.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/08/09/danny-ings-completes-20m-southampton-move/ |title=Danny Ings completes £20m Southampton move |first1=Chris |last1=Bascombe |first2=Jeremy |last2=Wilson |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=9 August 2018 |accessdate=10 August 2018}} On 12 August, he made his debut as a second-half substitute in a goalless draw with former club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]].{{cite news |url=https://www.eurosport.com/football/premier-league/2018-2019/danny-ings-makes-debut-as-saints-draw-at-home-to-burnley_sto6886016/story.shtml |title=Danny Ings makes debut as Saints draw at home to Burnley |publisher=EuroSport |date=12 August 2018 |accessdate=6 September 2018}} He then scored on his first start five days later in a 2–1 defeat to [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] before netting the opening goal in Southampton's 2–0 win over [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] at the start of the following month, helping the club to their first win of the campaign.{{cite news |url=https://southamptonfc.com/news/2018-08-18/match-report-everton-vs-saints-premier-league-1819 |title=Saints beaten despite Ings's first goal |publisher=Southampton FC |date=18 August 2018 |accessdate=6 September 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/sep/01/crystal-palace-southampton-premier-league-match-report |title=Danny Ings stuns Crystal Palace as Southampton claim first league win |first=Paul |last=MacInnes |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=1 September 2018 |accessdate=6 September 2018}} ==International career== On 3 October 2013, Ings received his first international call-up to the [[England national under-21 football team|England national under-21 team]] by manager [[Gareth Southgate]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24386221 "Liverpool winger Raheem Sterling in England Under-21 squad"] BBC Sport. 3 October 2013. Retrieved 20 November 2013. He made his debut a week later as a substitute in a 4–0 win away to [[San Marino national under-21 football team|San Marino]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24484759 "San Marino U21s 0–4 England U21s: Harry Kane nets hat-trick"] BBC Sport. 10 October 2013. Retrieved 20 November 2013. He won his second [[Cap (sport)|cap]] in the reverse fixture on 19 November, and scored twice as England won 9–0 against San Marino at the [[New Meadow]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24961625 "England U21 9–0 San Marino"] BBC Sport. 19 November 2013. Retrieved 20 November 2013. He earned 13 caps and scored four goals for the under-21s from 2013 to 2015.{{cite web |title=Danny Ings |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/all-teams/players/i/danny-ings |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=25 June 2015}} On 1 October 2015, Ings received his first international call-up to the full [[England national football team|England national team]] from manager [[Roy Hodgson]], for the final [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]] matches against [[Estonia national football team|Estonia]] and [[Lithuania national football team|Lithuania]].{{cite news qualifiers |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=27 April 2016}} He made his debut in the latter match on 12 October, replacing [[Harry Kane]] after 59 minutes of an eventual 3–0 win in
