(on loan from [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]) | clubnumber = 31 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[Vasas SC|Vasas]] | years1 = 2005–2007 | clubs1 = [[Vasas SC|Vasas]] | caps1 = 0 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2006 | clubs2 = → [[Vecsési FC|Vecsés]] (loan) | caps2 = 9 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2007–2015 | clubs3 = [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] | caps3 = 104 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2009 | clubs4 = → [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] (loan) | caps4 = 1 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2015– | clubs5 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] | caps5 = 2 | goals5 = 0 | years6 = 2016 | clubs6 = → [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] (loan) | caps6 = 17 | goals6 = 0 | years7 = 2018– | clubs7 = → [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] (loan) | caps7 = 18 | goals7 = 0 | pcupdate = 05:51, 3 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalyears1 = 2007–2008 | nationalteam1 = [[Hungary national under-21 football team|Hungary U21]] | nationalcaps1 = 7 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2011– | nationalteam2 = [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]] | nationalcaps2 = 20 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | ntupdate = 23:59, 26 March 2016 (UTC) }} '''Ádám Bogdán''' ({{IPA-hu|ˈaːdaːm ˈboɡdaːn}}; born 27 September 1987) is a Hungarian professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]], on loan from [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], and the [[Hungary national football team|Hungary national team]]. Bogdán began his career in Hungary at [[Vasas SC|Vasas]] before spending time on loan at [[Vecsési FC|Vecsés]]. In 2007, he moved to English club [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]], for whom he made 120 appearances across all competitions, before moving to Liverpool in 2015. Rarely used at Liverpool, he had a loan at [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] in 2016, cut short by injury. He made his senior international debut in 2011. Bogdán has since earned 20 caps and represented Hungary in [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification]] matches. ==Club career== ===Early career=== Born in [[Budapest]], Bogdán started his career with Hungarian [[Nemzeti Bajnokság I]] (Division One) team [[Vasas SC]]. He also had a loan spell at [[Vecsési FC|Vecsés]] where in his 9 games he impressed Bolton scouts.{{cite web|title=ÁDÁM BOGDÁN profile|url=http://www.hungarianfootball.com/player-profiles/adam-bogdan/|website=hungarianfootball.com|accessdate=24 September 2015}} ===Bolton Wanderers=== He signed for [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on a two-year contract on 1 August 2007.{{Cite news|first=Mark|last=Buckingham|title=Bolton bag Hungary keeper|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,12875_2636279,00.html|publisher=Sky Sports|date=1 August 2007|accessdate=29 August 2010}} His contract was extended in 2009 until June 2011.{{Cite news|title=Bogdan Thrilled To Extend His Deal|url=http://www.bwfc.co.uk/page/General/0,,1004~1511375,00.html|publisher=Bolton Wanderers F.C.|date=7 January 2009|accessdate=25 April 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716194006/http://www.bwfc.co.uk/page/General/0,,1004~1511375,00.html|archivedate=16 July 2011}} In September 2009, Bogdán joined [[Football League Two|League Two]] team [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] on a one-month [[loan (association football)|loan]].{{Cite news|title=Crewe sign Bolton keeper Bogdan|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/crewe_alexandra/8278719.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 September 2009|accessdate=29 August 2010}} He made his debut on 29 September 2009 in a 3–2 home defeat to [[Bury F.C.|Bury]], during which he made an error that cost Alexandra a point.{{Cite news|title=Crewe 2–3 Bury|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/8271066.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 September 2009|accessdate=29 August 2010}} He made his Bolton debut in a 1–0 [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] victory over [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 24 August 2010.{{Cite news|title=Southampton 0–1 Bolton|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8936599.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=24 August 2010|accessdate=25 August 2010}} On 29 August 2010, Bogdán made his [[Premier League]] debut when he replaced [[Jussi Jääskeläinen]], who had been sent off for violent conduct, 37 minutes into the home game against [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]].{{Cite news|last=Whyatt|first=Chris|title=Bolton 2–2 Birmingham|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8946659.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 August 2010|accessdate=29 August 2010}} He made his first Premier League start in the away game at [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] on 11 September. Following Jääskeläinen's return, Bogdán returned to the bench but manager [[Owen Coyle]] gave Bogdán starts in both the League Cup and [[FA Cup]]. On 31 March 2011, he signed an extension to his existing contract, which would keep him at the club until 2014.{{Cite news|title=Bolton tie down young goalkeeper Bogdán to new three-year deal at the Reebok|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1371872/Adam-Bogdan-signs-new-Bolton-contract-2014.html?|work=Daily Mail|date=31 March 2011|accessdate=31 March 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/b/bolton_wanderers/9441933.stm|title=Bolton goalkeeper Adam Bogdan signs contract until 2014|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 March 2011|accessdate=31 March 2011}} The [[2011–12 Bolton Wanderers F.C. season|2011–12 season]] gave Bogdán more playing time after Jääskeläinen suffered an injury during an international break,{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/sport/adam-bogdans-slow-rise-to-top-at-bolton-worth-the-wait|title=Adam Bogdan's slow rise to top at Bolton worth the wait|work=The National|date=18 January 2012|accessdate=18 January 2012}} but in his first league game, on 2 October, he conceded five goals against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and Jääskeläinen returned for the next league game. Three months later on 4 January, after Jääskeläinen suffered another injury, Bogdán returned for a game at [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] where he was beaten by a 102-yard wind assisted clearance by [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] goalkeeper [[Tim Howard]] from his own penalty area in a 2–1 victory at [[Goodison Park]].{{Cite news|title=Everton 1 – 2 Bolton|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/16343401.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=4 January 2012|accessdate=5 January 2012}} On 14 January 2012, Bogdán saved a [[penalty kick]] from [[Wayne Rooney]], although Bolton lost 3–0 to [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].{{cite web|url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/sport/football/bolton_wanderers/s/1470802_adam-bogdan-out-to-be-boltons-no1|title=Adam Bogdan out to be Bolton's No.1 |work=Manchester Evening News|date=16 January 2012|accessdate=16 January 2012}} He performed well during Jääskeläinen's absence and when the Finn returned from injury, Bogdán kept his place for the home game against Arsenal on 1 February, in which he kept a clean sheet in a goalless draw. Despite Jääskeläinen's return to full fitness, Bogdán remained first choice goalkeeper. On 11 March 2012, after Bolton's victory over [[QPR]], and on 1 April 2012, after Bolton's 3–2 victory over [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]], Bogdán was selected for in the "team of the week" by [[Garth Crooks]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17334957|title=Garth Crooks's team of the week |publisher=BBC Sport|date=11 March 2012|accessdate=11 March 2012}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17580431|title=Garth Crooks's team of the week |publisher=BBC Sport|date=1 April 2012|accessdate=1 April 2012}} On 14 May 2012, Bolton Wanderers held their annual end of season dinner, with Bogdán the recipient of the main accolade as he was named the club's Player of the Year, which is voted by the supporters.{{cite web|url=http://www.bwfc.co.uk/page/General/0,,1004~2771857,00.html|title=Bogdan Named Player of the Year|publisher=Bolton Wanderers F.C.|date=14 May 2012|accessdate=25 April 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120516081607/http://www.bwfc.co.uk/page/General/0,,1004~2771857,00.html|archivedate=16 May 2012}} Bogdán admitted he felt mixed emotions after getting the award{{cite web|url=http://www.bwfc.co.uk/page/General/0,,1004~2772157,00.html|title=Mixed Emotions For Bogdan|publisher=Bolton Wanderers F.C.|date=14 May 2012|accessdate=25 April 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120516081618/http://www.bwfc.co.uk/page/General/0,,1004~2772157,00.html|archivedate=16 May 2012}} due to the draw against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] which resulted in Bolton's relegation from the [[Premier League]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17973085|title=Bolton's 11-year stay in the Premier League has come to an end after being held to a draw at Stoke|publisher=BBC Sport|date=14 May 2012|accessdate=14 May 2012}} Bogdán signed a contract extension on 29 November 2012, which extended his contract to summer 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.bwfc.co.uk/news/article/contract-extension-for-bogdan-29.11.12-516528.aspx|title=Contract Extension For Bogdan|publisher=Bolton Wanderers F.C.|date=29 November 2012|accessdate=29 November 2012}} During the 2014–15 season, Bogdán only made 10 appearances for Bolton, after being displaced as the team's first-choice goalkeeper by [[Andy Lonergan]]. ===Liverpool=== On 12 June 2015, it was confirmed that Bogdán would join [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on a free transfer on 1 July, when his contract expired.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33107895|title=Adam Bogdan: Liverpool sign Bolton Wanderers goalkeeper|publisher=BBC Sport|date=12 June 2015|accessdate=12 June 2015}} He made his debut on 23 September, in a [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] third round tie against [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] at [[Anfield]], and saved three penalties in the shootout, enabling his side to win the shootout 3–2.{{cite web|title=Liverpool 1–1 Carlisle|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34265500|publisher=BBC Sport}} On 20 December, he made his Premier League debut for the Reds in a 3–0 loss to [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] at [[Vicarage Road]], dropping a corner kick after three minutes to allow [[Nathan Aké]] to open the scoring.{{cite news|last1=Barlow|first1=Matt|title=Watford 3–0 Liverpool: Nathan Ake capitalises on Adam Bogdan howler and Odion Ighalo strikes to condemn Jurgen Klopp's men to defeat as Hornets move a point off the Premier League top four|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3367794/Watford-3-0-Liverpool-Nathan-Ake-capitalises-Adam-Bogdan-howler-Odion-Ighalo-strikes-condemn-Jurgen-Klopp-s-men-defeat-Hornets-point-Premier-League-four.html|accessdate=21 December 2015|work=Daily Mail|date=20 December 2015}} Bogdán also played in a much-changed Liverpool side away to [[Exeter City]] on 8 January 2016 in the third round of the FA Cup, conceding direct from [[Lee Holmes]]' corner kick in a 2–2 draw.{{cite web|url =https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35155398|title=Exeter City 2 – 2 Liverpool|date=8 January 2016|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=8 January 2016}} On the last match of the 2015–16 Premier League season, Bogdán was named in the starting line up against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Brom]] after a long absence from the first team squad. West Brom opened the scoring through [[Salomón Rondón]] in the 13th minute, before [[Jordon Ibe]] leveled in the 23rd minute – the match ended in a 1–1 draw.{{cite web|url =https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2016/05/15/england/premier-league/west-bromwich-albion-football-club/liverpool-fc/2043606/?ICID=PL_MS_04|title=West Bromwich 1 – 1 Liverpool|date=15 May 2016|work=Soccerway|accessdate=17 May 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36240499|title=West Bromwich Albion 1–1 Liverpool|date=15 May 2016|publisher=BBC Sport}} On 20 July 2016, Bogdán joined Wigan Athletic on loan for the 2016–17 season.{{Cite news |title=Adam Bogdan joins Wigan on season-long loan |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/228317-adam-bogdan-joins-wigan-on-season-long-loan |publisher=Liverpool FC |date=20 July 2016 |accessdate=20 July 2016}} Bogdán made 17 appearances for Wigan, keeping five clean sheets. In his final game, a 0–0 draw against [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] on 19 November, Bogdán suffered a tear in his [[anterior cruciate ligament]] and was substituted in the 59th minute. Bogdán then returned to his parent club Liverpool for rehabilitation.{{Cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/adam-bogdan-returns-liverpool-after-12210823|title=Bogdan returns to Liverpool after loan deal cut short|last=Pearce|first=James|date=2016-11-22|work=liverpoolecho|accessdate=2017-04-17}} On 2 July 2018, Bogdán moved on a season-long loan to [[Scottish Premiership]] club [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]].{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44686135 |title=Adam Bogdan: Liverpool goalkeeper joins Hibs on loan |work= |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 July 2018 |accessdate=2 July 2018}} ==International career== [[File:Bogdan2011.png|thumb|200px|Bogdán playing for [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]] in 2011]] Bogdán received his first call up for [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]] in October 2008, and was an unused substitute in their 1–0 win over [[Malta national football team|Malta]]. In June 2011 he made his first full international appearance, in a 1–0 win against [[Luxembourg national football team|Luxembourg]]. He was named as Hungarian Player of the Year for 2012.{{cite web |url=http://pepsifoci.hu/node/129618 |title=Bogdán Ádám az év magyar játékosa | csakfoci.hu |publisher=Pepsifoci.hu |accessdate=2014-04-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121216045134/http://pepsifoci.hu/node/129618 |archivedate=16 December 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.mancunianmatters.co.uk/content/111064333-crunch-time-bolton-wanderers%E2%80%99-keeper-adam-bogdan-hungary-seek-first-world-cup-spot |title=Crunch time for Bolton Wanderers' keeper Adam Bogdan as Hungary seek first World Cup spot since 1986 |publisher=Mancunian Matters |date=2013-10-11 |accessdate=2016-01-30}} On 11 October 2013, he kept goal in the nation's record defeat, 1–8 to the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]] at the [[Amsterdam Arena]] in [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification|2014 World Cup qualification]].{{cite news|last1=Scholten|first1=Berend|title=Van Persie sets scoring record in Dutch romp|url=http://www.uefa.com/worldcup/season=2014/matches/round=2000294/match=2008621/postmatch/report/|accessdate=12 June 2015|date=11 October 2013}} ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|05:51, 3 March 2019 (UTC)}}{{cite web|title=A. (on loan from [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]) |clubnumber = 18 |youthyears1 = 2005–2014 |youthclubs1 = [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] |youthyears2 = 2014–2016 |youthclubs2 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] |years1 = 2016– |clubs1 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] |caps1 = 2 |goals1 = 0 |years2 = 2018 |clubs2 = → [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] (loan) |caps2 = 11 |goals2 = 1 |years3 = 2018 |clubs3 = → [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] (loan) |caps3 = 14 |goals3 = 1 |years4 = 2019– |clubs4 = → [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] (loan) |caps4 = 7|goals4 = 1 |nationalyears1 = 2016–2017 |nationalteam1 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] |nationalcaps1 = 7 |nationalgoals1 = 2 |nationalyears2 = 2018– |nationalteam2 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] |nationalcaps2 = 1 |nationalgoals2 = 0 |club-update = 00:13, 3 March 2019 (UTC) |ntupdate = 16:47, 24 March 2018 (UTC) }} '''Oviemuno Dominic Ejaria''' (born 18 November 1997) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] on loan from [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].https://www.skysports.com/amp/football/news/11669/11601086/liverpool-midfielder-ovie-ejaria-to-join-reading-on-loan He is a current [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] international. ==Club career== ===Liverpool=== Born in London to Nigerian parents, Ejaria grew up supporting [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] for whom he played for nine years before signing for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in summer 2014. His first senior appearance was in a pre-season [[Exhibition game#Association football|friendly]] prior to the [[2016-17 Premier League|2016-17 season]] against [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere Rovers]] on 8 July 2016.{{cite web|last=Williams|first=Sam|title= Ings winner decides Tranmere friendly|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/226938-match-report-ings-winner-decides-tranmere-friendly|publisher=Liverpool F.C.|accessdate=26 October 2016|date=8 July 2016}} Despite being relatively unknown prior to the game he performed exceptionally well and caught the eye of first team manager [[Jürgen Klopp]] who selected him for four more friendlies over the summer.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} His first competitive call-up came on 16 September in a [[Premier League]] match against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]. He was an unused substitute in Liverpool's 2–1 victory.{{cite web|last=McNulty|first=Phil|title=Chelsea 2-1 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37314772|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=26 October 2016|date=16 September 2016}} Four days later, he made his first team debut against [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] in the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] replacing [[Roberto Firmino]] in the 3–0 victory.{{cite web|title=Derby County 0-3 Liverpool |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37346111|author=|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=26 October 2016|date=20 September 2016}} On 25 October, Ejaria made his full debut in the fourth round of the EFL Cup in a 2–1 win over against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham]] at [[Anfield]].{{cite web|title=Liverpool 2-1 Tottenham |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37686653|author=Luke Reddy|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=26 October 2016|date=25 October 2016}} On 6 November 2016, he debuted in the Premier League, coming on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in Liverpool's 6–1 home win over [[Watford F.C.|Watford]].{{cite web|first=Patrick|last=Jennings|title=Liverpool 6-1 Watford|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37814248|publisher=BBC Sport|date=6 November 2016|accessdate=7 November 2016}} ====Loan to Sunderland==== On 31 January 2018, Ejaria made a deadline day switch to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]], signing on loan for the remainder of the season.{{Cite web | title = Ovie Ejaria, Ashley Fletcher and Lee Camp join Sunderland | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 1 February 2018 | accessdate = 1 February 2018 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42896591}} He made 11 appearances in total as the club were relegated to [[EFL League One|League One]].{{cite news|url=https://www.thisisanfield.com/2018/06/steven-gerrard-set-to-make-his-first-signing-from-liverpool/|title=Steven Gerrard set to make his first signing from Liverpool|publisher=Liverpool Echo|last=Matchett|first=Karl|date=3 June 2018|accessdate=3 June 2018}} His only goal, and his first in senior football, came in the final match of the regular season when he opened the scoring in a 3–0 win over the eventual league champions, [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolves]].{{cite news|url=http://www.espnfc.com.ng/report?gameId=483159|title=Relegated Sunderland end season with emphatic victory over champions Wolves|publisher=ESPN|date=6 May 2018|accessdate=7 June 2018}} ====Loan to Rangers==== In June 2018, Ejaria moved on loan to [[Scottish Premiership]] club [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]], managed by former Liverpool captain and academy coach [[Steven Gerrard]], after signing a new long-term contract with Liverpool.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44399483 |title=Rangers sign Liverpool midfielder Ovie Ejaria on a season-long loan |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |date=7 June 2018 |accessdate=7 June 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/304170-ovie-ejaria-liverpool-fc-deal-loan-rangers|title=Ejaria signs new LFC deal, joins Rangers on loan|publisher=Liverpool F.C.|last=Lynch|first=David|date=7 June 2018|accessdate=13 July 2018}} He made his debut on 12 July, coming on as a second-half substitute in Rangers' 2–0 [[UEFA Europa League]] win over Macedonian side [[FK Shkupi|Shkupi]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/live/football/44769909|title=Europa League: Hibs hit six, Rangers win in Gerrard's first game|publisher=BBC Sport|last1=Palmer|first1=Bryn|last2=Southwick|first2=Andrew|date=12 July 2018|accessdate=13 July 2018}} He scored his first goal for the club in a [[Scottish Premiership]] match against Motherwell on 26 August.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45237301|title=Motherwell 3-3 Rangers|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 August 2018|accessdate=28 August 2018}} In December 2018 his loan was curtailed earlier than planned and he returned to training with Liverpool.https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/330371-ovie-ejaria-liverpool-rangers ====Loan to Reading==== A loan move to [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] was announced on January 7, 2019.https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46788125 ==International career== Ejaria is eligible to represent [[England]] or [[Nigeria]] internationally. He trained with the [[Nigeria national under-17 football team|Nigeria Under-17]]s team in 2013 and stated that his international allegiance lay with the country in 2014.{{cite news|last1=Prentice|first1=David|title=Liverpool starlet Ovie Ejaria set for international call up before making a first team appearance|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpool-starlet-ovie-ejaria-set-11681482|accessdate=6 November 2016|work=Liverpool Echo|date=29 July 2016}} However, despite rumours of a senior Nigeria call up being in the offing, Ejaria accepted a call up to the [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] team on 30 September 2016.{{cite web|last1=Lusby|first1=Jack|title=Ovie Ejaria called up to England U20 squad, despite previous Nigeria allegiance|url=http://www.thisisanfield.com/2016/09/ovie-ejaria-called-england-u20-squad-despite-previous-nigeria-allegiance/|website=This is Anfield|accessdate=6 November 2016|date=30 September 2016}} He made his debut for the Under-20 team on 7 October, in a 3–1 win against Germany, playing the whole match.{{cite web|title=Calvert-Lewin and Lookman fire Lions to win over Germany|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2016/oct/07/u20s-germany-report-071016|website=The FA|accessdate=6 November 2016|date=7 October 2016}} Ejaria was selected for the [[England national under-20 football team|England under-20 team]] in the [[2017 FIFA U-20 World Cup]]. He made his first start in a game in the first round match against South Korea,{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpool-pair-ovie-ejaria-sheyi-13097937 |title=Liverpool pair Ovie Ejaria and Sheyi Ojo help England continue their World Cup dream |first=Neil|last= Jones|date= 26 May 2017 |work=Liverpool Echo}} and came on as a substitute the quarter-final against Mexico,{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/265542-ejaria-features-as-england-u20s-reach-world-cup-semi-final |title=Ejaria features as England U20s reach World Cup semi-final|first=Steve|last= Hunter|date= 5 June 2017|work=Liverpool FC }} but was an unused substitute in the final where England beat Venezuela 1–0.{{cite news |url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40237981 |title= Under-20 World Cup: England beat Venezuela in final |work=BBC Sport |date= 11 June 2017 }} He was called up for the [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21 team]] in March 2018, making his debut in a friendly against Romania.{{cite news |url = http://www.skysports.com/football/news/16261/11303332/jake-clarke-salter-ovie-ejaria-ademola-lookman-young-lions-impress-in-england-u21s-victory|title= Jake Clarke-Salter, Ovie Ejaria, Ademola Lookman: Young Lions impress in England U21s victory |work=Sky Sports |date= 24 March 2018}} He was called up again in May 2018 for the [[Toulon Tournament]]{{cite news |url = https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/302380-ovie-ejaria-england-u21-toulon |title=Ejaria named in England U21s' Toulon Tournament squad |work=Liverpool FC |date= 18 May 2018}} but had to withdraw from the squad due to an injury.{{cite news |url = https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/303257-liverpool-fc-ovie-ejaria-england-u21s |title= Ejaria withdraws from England U21 squad Ojo joined Liverpool as a 14-year-old and came through their [[Liverpool F.C. Reserves and Academy|academy]]. He spent time on loan with [[EFL Championship|Championship]] clubs [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] and [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] before making his competitive debut for Liverpool in January 2016. Ojo has represented England at [[England national under-16 football team|under-16]], [[England national under-17 football team|under-17]], [[England national under-18 football team|under-18]], [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]], [[England national under-20 football team|under-20]] and [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] levels. ==Club career== ===Early career=== Ojo joined [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|MK Dons]]' academy when he was 10 years old. By the age of 13, he had played for the Dons' U18 side and was training with the first team squad.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/15780917 |title=Liverpool sign up MK Dons schoolboy Seyi Ojo |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 November 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2015}} During his time at the club, Ojo became the first MK Dons trainee to receive an international cap at youth level.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/nov/17/liverpool-mk-dons-seyi-ojo |title=Liverpool sign MK Dons teenage midfielder Seyi Ojo |work=The Guardian |date=17 November 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2015}} ===Liverpool=== On 11 November 2011, Liverpool beat off competition from a host of Europe's top clubs{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/news/showbiz-news/exclusive---meet-teenage-dream-8314038 |title=Exclusive – meet a teenage dream team: rising Liverpool FC star Sheyi Ojo and aspiring beauty queen and actress Amaani Noor |first=Paddy |last=Shennan |work=Liverpool Echo |date=18 December 2014 |accessdate=7 February 2015}} including a multimillion-pound offer from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2049367/Chelsea-pay-2m-14-year-old-Oluwaseyi-Ojo.html |title=Chelsea pay £2m for 14-year-old Oluwaseyi Ojo |work=Daily Mail |first=Sami |last=Mokbel |date=14 October 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2015}} to sign Ojo, then 14, for an undisclosed fee believed to be in the region of £2 million. In April 2014, Ojo was joint top scorer alongside fellow Liverpool player [[Harry Wilson (footballer, born 1997)|Harry Wilson]] in the prestigious U17 [[Future Cup]]. ====Loan to Wigan==== Having made a number of appearances on Liverpool's bench over the festive period, Ojo joined [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] on loan on 2 February 2015.{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11682/9696365/transfer-news-wigan-sign-liverpool-winger-sheyi-ojo-on-loan |title=Transfer news: Wigan sign Liverpool winger Sheyi Ojo on loan |publisher=Sky Sports |date=2 February 2015 |accessdate=30 January 2016}} Five days later, he made his professional debut coming on as a 59th-minute substitute for Wigan in a Championship match against [[AFC Bournemouth]], with Wigan naming Ojo as their Man of the Match after he had a positive impact on the game.{{cite web |url=http://www.thisisanfield.com/2015/02/loan-watch-lfc-youngster-earns-man-match-professional-debut-despite-playing-30-minutes/ |title=Loan Watch: LFC youngster earns man of match on professional debut – despite only playing 30 minutes! |publisher=This Is Anfield |date=26 January 2016 |accessdate=30 January 2016}}{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31070531 |title=Wigan Athletic 1–3 Bournemouth |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 February 2015 |accessdate=30 January 2016}} ==== Loan to Wolverhampton ==== On 2 August 2015, Ojo scored the winning goal for Liverpool in a friendly against [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]].{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3183085/Swindon-1-2-Liverpool-Christian-Benteke-scores-stunning-volley-debut-Reds-complete-preparations-ahead-Stoke-test.html |title=Swindon 1–2 Liverpool: Christian Benteke scores stunning volley on debut as Reds complete preparations ahead of Stoke test |last=Crafton |first=Adam |date=2 August 2015 |work=Daily Mail |accessdate=30 January 2016}} In 4 August 2015, Liverpool announced that Ojo had signed a new long-term contract with the club and confirmed that he would join [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on a season-long loan.{{cite web |title=New Reds deal and loan switch for Ojo |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/latest-news/190040-new-reds-deal-and-loan-switch-for-ojo |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |date=3 August 2015 |accessdate=4 August 2015}} He made his Wolves debut on the opening day of the 2015–16 Championship season as a substitute, coming on in the 84th minute and picking up a yellow card as his side went on to beat [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]]. Three days later, he made his first start for Wolves in a 2–1 League Cup win over [[Newport County A.F.C.|Newport County]], assisting [[Nouha Dicko]] for Wolves' opening goal.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/33769181 |title=Wolverhampton Wanderers 2–1 Newport County |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 August 2015 |accessdate=15 November 2016}} ====Return to Liverpool==== He was recalled by Liverpool on 7 January 2016.{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11669/10121367/liverpool-recall-sheyi-ojo-from-wolves-loan-spell |title=Liverpool recall Sheyi Ojo from Wolves loan spell |publisher=Sky Sports |first=Mike |last=Patterson |date=7 January 2016 |accessdate=7 January 2016}} The next day, Ojo made his competitive first-team debut for Liverpool, as a substitute in the [[FA Cup]] [[2015–16 FA Cup#Third Round Proper|Third Round]] tie against [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] that ended in a 2–2 draw.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35155398 |title=Exeter City 2–2 Liverpool |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Gary |last=Rose |date=8 January 2016 |accessdate=8 January 2016}} He scored his first competitive goal for Liverpool in the replay against Exeter on 20 January; his goal was the second in a 3–0 victory.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/35299326 |title=Liverpool 3–0 Exeter City |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Aimee |last=Lewis |date=20 January 2016 |accessdate=21 January 2016}} Ojo made his [[Premier League]] debut on 20 March 2016, replacing [[Joe Allen (footballer, born 1990)|Joe Allen]] in the 87th minute in a 3–2 loss away to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] at [[St Mary's Stadium]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35796778 |title=Southampton 3–2 Liverpool |publisher=BBC Sport |first=Mike |last=Henson |date=20 March 2016 |accessdate=20 March 2016}} Three weeks later, he made his first start for Liverpool in the Premier League against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] at [[Anfield]], where he assisted [[Daniel Sturridge]] for Liverpool's second goal in a 4–1 win, before being replaced by [[Divock Origi]].{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpool-boss-jurgen-klopp-kevin-11166081 |title=Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp on Kevin Stewart and Sheyi Ojo |work=Liverpool Echo |first=Joe |last=Rimmer |date=10 April 2016 |accessdate=10 April 2016}} Ahead of the 2016–17 season, Ojo sustained a fracture in his back and did not return to first team training until mid-November.{{cite news |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/sheyi-ojo-klopp-liverpool-injury-12172276 |title=Sheyi Ojo hands Liverpool boss Klopp another injury boost |work=Liverpool Echo |first=Kristian |last=Walsh |date=14 November 2016 |accessdate=14 November 2016}} ====Loan to Fulham==== On 16 August 2017, Ojo joined [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on season-long loan.{{cite news |title=Sheyi Ojo: Liverpool forward joins Fulham on loan for 2017–18 season |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/40950777 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 August 2017}} He scored a double in a 5–4 win over [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]], on 21 November.{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/41978135 |title=Sheffield United 4–5 Fulham |date=21 November 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport|access-date=30 August 2018 }} He scored the winning goal in a 1–0 win over [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]], on 9 December.{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/42205336 |title=Fulham 1–0 Birmingham City |date=9 December 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport|access-date=30 August 2018 }} On 23 December, Ojo received a yellow card and scored in a 2–1 win over [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]].{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/42375408 |title=Fulham 2–1 Barnsley |date=23 December 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport|access-date=30 August 2018 }} ==== Loan to Stade de Reims ==== On 30 August 2018, Ojo signed a new contract with Liverpool and joined [[Stade de Reims]] on a season-long loan.{{Cite news |url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/314115-sheyi-ojo-new-contract-loan-liverpool |title=Sheyi Ojo signs new deal and makes loan move |work=Liverpool FC|access-date=30 August 2018}} ==International career== As Ojo was born in England, he is eligible to represent [[England national football team|England]] and through his [[Nigerians|Nigerian]] heritage is also eligible to play for [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] in international football. Ojo has represented England at [[England national under-16 football team|under-16]], [[England national under-17 football team|under-17]], [[England national under-18 football team|under-18]] and [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] levels. In his early teens, Ojo often played at a higher age group at international level, representing England U17s at the St George's Park Tournament in 2012 aged 15.{{cite web |url=https://theyouthradar.com/2012/08/07/england-under-17s-squad-named-for-early-season-tournament/ |title=England Under 17s Squad Named For Early Season Tournament |publisher=The Youth Radar |first=Tom |last=Bennett |date=7 August 2012 |accessdate=15 November 2016}} Ojo represented England U17s in the 2014 Algarve Tournament, with England coming second to Germany after a 1–0 loss in the final game.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2014/mar/england-u17s-v-germany-algarve-tournament-match-report-020314 |title=England Under-17 suffer late heartbreak in the Algarve |publisher=The Football Association |first=Gary |last=Stonehouse |date=2 March 2014 |accessdate=30 January 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141013165511/http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2014/mar/england-u17s-v-germany-algarve-tournament-match-report-020314 |archivedate=13 October 2014}} In September 2014, Ojo received his first [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] call-up for a double header against the Netherlands. Ojo appeared in both games with England winning by an aggregate score of 7–2.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2014/aug/holland-bury-september-squad-neil-dewsnip-ledson-u17-euros-champions-woodman-kenny |title=Neil Dewsnip names U18 squad |publisher=The Football Association |date=26 August 2014 |accessdate=30 January 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140829013216/http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2014/aug/holland-bury-september-squad-neil-dewsnip-ledson-u17-euros-champions-woodman-kenny |archivedate=29 August 2014}} On 27 August 2015, Ojo received his first call-up to the [[England national under-19 football team|England U19 team]] and played 90 minutes in a 3–2 away win over [[Germany national under-19 football team|Germany]].{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/192680-rossiter-and-ojo-in-england-u19-squad |title=Rossiter and Ojo in England U19 squad |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |first=David |last=Lynch |date=27 August 2015 |accessdate=30 January 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2015/sep/match-report-germany-v-england-u19s-040915 |title=England U19s pick up thrilling victory in Germany |publisher=The Football Association |first=Gary |last=Stonehouse |date=4 September 2015 |accessdate=30 January 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160205000006/http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2015/sep/match-report-germany-v-england-u19s-040915 |archivedate=5 February 2016}} Later in the same tournament, he started against France and helped ''The Young Lions'' secure a 2–1 win by providing 2 assists.{{cite web |url=http://www.thisisanfield.com/2016/07/sheyi-ojo-provides-two-assists-england-u19s-defeat-france/ |title=Sheyi Ojo provides two assists as England U19s defeat France |publisher=This Is Anfield |first=Emma |last=Sanders |date=12 July 2016 |accessdate=13 July 2016}} Ojo was selected for the [[England national under-20 football team|England under-20 team]] in the [[2017 FIFA U-20 World Cup]]. Ojo made his start in tournament in the match against Guinea,{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpool-pair-ovie-ejaria-sheyi-13097937 |title=Liverpool pair Ovie Ejaria and Sheyi Ojo help England continue their World Cup dream |first=Neil |last=Jones |date=26 May 2017 |work=Liverpool Echo}} and was a substitute in a few other games, including the semifinal match against Italy in which he assisted in two of the goals.{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/06/08/england-u20s-vs-italy-u20s-world-cup-semi-final-live-score-updates/ |title=England U20s 3 Italy U20s 1: Dominic Solanke fires Three Lions to first World Cup final since 1966 |authors=Chris Bascombe, Alistair Tweedale |date=8 June 2017 |work=The Daily Telegraph}} In the final, Ojo came on as a substitute for [[Kieran Dowell]] in the 62nd minute. England beat Venezuela 1–0, which is England's first win in a global tournament since their [[1966 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] victory of 1966.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40237981 |title=Under-20 World Cup: England beat Venezuela in final |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 June 2017}} In September 2018 he stated he could represent Nigeria in future.{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45619397 |title=Sheyi Ojo: England U20 World Cup winner open to representing Nigeria |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 September 2018}} ==Personal life== Born in [[Hemel Hempstead]], England, his name "Babajide" is a variant form of the [[Yoruba language|Yoruba]] name: [[Babatunde]], meaning "Father has Returned" or "Father Comes Back to Life".{{cite web |url=http://www.behindthename.com/name/babatunde |title=Babatunde |publisher=Behind the Name |accessdate=15 November 2016}} During his time with the Liverpool Football Academy, Ojo was a student at [[Rainhill High School|Rainhill Media Arts College]], in [[Rainhill]], England.{{cite web |title=LFC Academy Education Centre [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]. ==Club career== ===Liverpool=== Born in [[Valencia]], Spain, Chirivella developed his trade at the academy of local club [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] where he captained the club at various youth levels.{{cite web|url=https://liverpoolfcacademynews.wordpress.com/2013/06/21/who-is-pedro-chirivella/|website=The Liverpool FC Academy Football Blog|title=Who is Pedro Chirivella?|date=21 June 2013|accessdate=4 January 2017}} During his time with Valencia, Chirivella was scouted by a number of European clubs but it was [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] who signed him in 2013 along with fellow Spaniard [[Sergi Canós]] from [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisanfield.com/2015/08/sergi-canos-liverpools-former-barcelona-academy-forward-profile/|title=Sergi Canos: Liverpool’s former Barcelona academy forward in profile|website=This is Anfield|last=Lusby|first=Jack|date=16 August 2016|accessdate=17 September 2015}} In order to aid Chirivella's transition to England, Liverpool moved his family north from Spain and provided them with work and accommodation.{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisanfield.com/2015/08/pedro-chirivella-lowdown-liverpools-spanish-academy-star/|title=Pedro Chirivella: The lowdown on Liverpool’s Spanish academy star|website=This is Anfield|date=14 August 2015|accessdate=4 January 2017|last=Lusby|first=Jack}} He joined up with Liverpool's academy and on 7 July 2014 was one of seven youngsters to be handed a professional contract by the club.{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/165933-seven-young-reds-sign-pro-contracts|title=Seven young Reds sign pro contracts|website=Liverpool F.C.|date=7 September 2014|accessdate=17 September 2015}} ====2015–16 season==== Chirivella received his first taste of senior football when he was included in club [[Manager (association football)|manager]] [[Brendan Rodgers]]' squad for Liverpool's pre-season tour of Asia and Australia.{{cite web|url=http://readliverpoolfc.com/2015/07/13/youngsters-on-pre-season-tour/|title=Youngsters on Pre-season Tour|website=Read Liverpool|last=Killen|first=Stephen|date=13 July 2015|accessdate=4 January 2017}} During the tour he made his non-competitive debut for Liverpool, coming on as a second-half [[substitute (association football)|substitute]] against [[Helsingin Jalkapalloklubi|HJK Helsinki]]. He received his first competitive call up later in the season for Liverpool's [[UEFA Europa League]] [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League group stage|group stage]] match against [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Bordeaux]] on 17 September 2015. In the 28th-minute, following an injury to centre-back [[Kolo Touré]], Chirivella was brought on to make his debut and played out the remainder of a 1–1 draw at the [[Nouveau Stade de Bordeaux]].{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/sep/17/liverpool-bordeaux-europa-league-match-report|title=Liverpool denied by Bordeaux’s Ferreira Jussiê in Europa League draw|date=14 September 2015|website=Guardian|last=Nakrani|first=Sachin|accessdate=18 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Bordeaux 1–1 Liverpool|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/34203664|website=BBC Sport|last=Chowdhury|first=Saj|accessdate=17 September 2015}} His next appearance for the club saw him make his [[FA Cup]] debut under new manager [[Jürgen Klopp]] on 8 January 2016 when he came on as a substitute in a third round match against [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]].{{cite web|url =https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/35155398|title=Exeter City – Liverpool|date=8 January 2016|website=BBC Sport|last=Rose|first=Gary|accessdate=8 January 2016}} Liverpool ultimately progressed in the Cup which afforded Chirivella the opportunity to make his first start for the club on 9 February 2016 in a 2–1 defeat against [[West Ham United]] in the fourth round replay.{{cite web|url =https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35467976|title=West Ham United – Liverpool|date=9 February 2016|website=BBC Sport|last=Jurejko|first=Jonathan|accessdate=9 February 2016}} Chirivella then signed a new contract with Liverpool on 9 March before making his Premier League debut towards the back end of the season, starting in a 3–1 loss against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] on 1 May.{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/210788-pedro-chirivella-signs-new-liverpool-contract|website=Liverpool Football Club|title=Pedro Chirivella signs new Liverpool contract|last=Shaw|first=Chris|date=9 March 2016|accessdate=4 January 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3567974/Liverpool-s-Pedro-Chirivella-latest-teenage-starlet-make-Premier-League-debut-he.html|title=Liverpool's Pedro Chirivella is the latest teenage starlet to make his Premier League debut ... But who is he?|website=Daily Mail|last=Bassam|first=Tom|date=1 May 2016|accessdate=4 January 2017}} ====2016–17 season: Loan to Go Ahead Eagles==== On 6 January 2017, Liverpool announced that Chirivella, who had spent the first half of the season playing for the club's U23 side, would spend the remainder of the season on loan at [[Eredivisie]] club, [[Go Ahead Eagles]] in order to gain more first team experience.{{cite web|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/249257-pedro-chirivella-joins-go-ahead-eagles-on-loan|title=Pedro Chirivella joins Go Ahead Eagles on loan |website=Liverpool Football Club|last=Lynch|first=David|date=6 January 2017|accessdate=6 January 2017}} He made his debut for the club on 13 January 2017, playing the full match in a 3–1 defeat to [[AZ Alkmaar]].{{cite web|url=https://www.eredivisie.nl/nieuwsbericht/chirivella-en-manu-in-basis-go-ahead-tegen-az|website=Eredivisie|language=nl|title=Chirivella en Manu in basis Go Ahead tegen AZ|date=12 January 2017|accessdate=19 January 2017}} The following week, Chirivella scored his first professional goal, heading in the opener from [[Jarchinio Antonia]]'s cross in a 1–1 draw with [[SBV Excelsior|Excelsior]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisanfield.com/2017/01/kent-chirivella-score-ward-fulton-keep-clean-sheets-liverpool-fc-loan-watch/|website=This is Anfield|title=Kent & Chirivella score, Ward & Fulton keep clean sheets – Liverpool FC Loan Watch|last=Twelves|first=Ben|date=23 January 2017|accessdate=23 January 2017}} He ultimately made 17 appearances for the campaign and scored twice but could not help prevent the club avoid relegation at the end of the season.{{cite web|url=http://www.footballinsider247.com/ill-never-forget-support-liverpool-farewell-twitter/|title=I'll Never Forget the Support - Liverpool Midfielder Sends Farewell to Fans on Twitter|website=Football Insider|last=Byrne|first=Harvey|date=15 May 2017|accessdate=15 May 2017}} ====2017–18 season: Loan to Willem II==== On 26 July 2017, Chirivella returned to Netherlands after being loaned to [[Willem II (football club)|Willem II]] for the season.{{cite news|title=Chirivella joins Willem II on season-long loan|url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/269689-chirivella-joins-willem-ii-on-season-long-loan|work=Liverpool FC}} He made his debut for the club on 13 August, starting in a 2–1 defeat to Excelsior.{{cite web|url=http://www.friendsofliverpool.com/2017/08/loan-report-awoniyi-makes-big-impression-debut/|title=The Loan Report: Awoniyi makes big impression on debut|website=Friends of Liverpool|last=Whitlock|first=Dominic|date=14 August 2017|accessdate=31 August 2017}} ====2018-19 season: Loan to Extremadura==== On 31 January 2019, he signed for Spanish club [[Extremadura UD]] on loan.{{cite news|title=Pedro Chirivella joins Extremadura UD on loan|url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/336281-pedro-chirivella-liverpool-extremadura-loan|work=Liverpool FC}} On 13 February, however, the club announced he could not play for the first team during the remainder of [[2018–19 Segunda División|the season]], as his transfer documentations arrived after the time limit.{{cite web|url=https://as.com/futbol/2019/02/13/segunda/1550070535_092285.html|title=Chirivella no podrá jugar en el Extremadura|trans-title=Chirivella will not be able to play at Extremadura|publisher=[[Diario AS]]|language=es|date=13 February 2019|accessdate=15 February 2019}} ==International career== Chirivella represented Spain at [[Spain national under-17 football team|under-17]] level and scored twice for them in 15 appearances. ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 6 May 2018}} {{soccerway|pedro-chirivella/274936|accessdate=4 January 2017}} {| team|Poland U21]] | nationalcaps3 = 2 | nationalgoals3 = 0 |club-update = 16:56, 23 August 2018 (UTC) }} '''Kamil Grabara''' (born 8 January 1999) is a Polish professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Aarhus Gymnastikforening|AGF]], on loan from [[Premier League]] club [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]]. ==Club career== Grabara joined Liverpool ahead of the [[2016–17 Liverpool F.C. season|2016–17 season]] from [[Ruch Chorzów]] for £250,000,{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jan/06/kamil-grabara-liverpool-sign-teenage-goalkeeper-ruch-warsaw|title=Liverpool sign teenage Polish keeper Kamil Grabara from Ruch Chorzow|first=Andy|last=Hunter|date=6 January 2016|publisher=|via=www.theguardian.com}}{{cite web|url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/team/first-team/player/kamil-grabara|title=Profile|accessdate=23 August 2018|publisher=Liverpool F.C.}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/who-kamil-grabara-liverpool-goalkeeper-12996084|title=Everything you need to know about Liverpool youngster Kamil Grabara|last=Smith|first=Alex|date=2018-07-28|work=mirror|access-date=2018-10-30}} and was promoted to the first team squad for the [[2018–19 Liverpool F.C. season|2018–19 season]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/liverpool-turn-teenage-goalkeepers-kamil-14962857|title=Liverpool turn to teenage goalkeepers against Man Utd|last=Walsh|first=Kristian|date=2018-07-27|work=liverpoolecho|access-date=2018-10-30}} He trains regularly with the first-team squad at [[Melwood]] and made his maiden senior outing in a pre-season friendly against [[Tranmere Rovers F.C.|Tranmere]] in July 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/meet-kamil-grabara-liverpools-fearless-14964745|title=Meet 'fearless' Grabara, the teenage keeper liked by Gerrard & United|first=James|last=Pearce|date=28 July 2018|website=liverpoolecho}} On 26 September 2018, Grabara was named on the substitutes’ bench for the first time in Liverpool’s 2-1 [[Football League Cup|Carabao Cup]] defeat to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] at Anfield.{{citeweb|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45569330|title=Liverpool 1-2 Chelsea - BBC Sport|}} On 6 January 2019, Grabara joined [[Aarhus Gymnastikforening|AGF]] on loan until the end of the season.{{cite web |url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/academy/333040-kamil-grabara-aarhus-liverpool-loan|title=Kamil Grabara joins AGF Aarhus on loan|publisher=Liverpool F.C.|date=6 January 2019|accessdate=6 January 2019}} ==International career== Grabara is a [[Poland under-21 national football team|Polish U21]] international having made his debut against Denmark on 14 November 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.uefa.com/under21/season=2019/teams/team=200109/index.html|title=Poland - U21 EURO|first=|last=UEFA.com|website=UEFA.com}} ==Style of play== Grabara is an accomplished, all-round goalkeeper, able to dominate the penalty area, pull out top reflex saves, play out from the back with composure and, as he develops, operate as a sweeper.{{cite web|url=https://www.thisisanfield.com/2018/07/kamil-grabara-liverpool-youngster-with-the-confidence-to-become-future-no-1/|title=Who is young Liverpool goalkeeper Kamil Grabara?|date=15 July 2018|publisher=}} ==Personal life== Grabara is from [[Ruda Śląska]], in south [[Poland]]. He is the second Pole to play in goal for the Reds after Champions League hero [[Jerzy Dudek]].{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/who-kamil-grabara-liverpool-goalkeeper-12996084|title=Everything you need to know about Liverpool youngster Kamil Grabara|first=Alex|last=Smith|date=28 July 2018|website=mirror}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.liverpoolfc.com/team/first-team/player/kamil-grabar Liverpool F.C. profile] * {{90minut|31168}} {{Aarhus Gymnastikforening squad}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Grabara, Kamil}} [[Category:1999 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Polish footballers]] [[Category:Polish expatriate footballers]] [[Category:Polish people]] [[Category:Polish sportspeople]] [[Category:Association football goalkeepers]] [[Category:Expatriate footballers in England]] [[Category:Polish expatriate sportspeople in England]] [[Category:Liverpool F.C. players]] [[Category:Aarhus Gymnastikforening players]] [[Category:Sportspeople from Ruda Śląska]] {{Poland-footy-goalkeeper-stub}}

(on loan from [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]) | clubnumber = |youthyears1 = 2010–2015 |youthclubs1 =Imperial Soccer Academy | years1 = 2015– | clubs1 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] | caps1 = 0 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2015–2016 | clubs2 = → [[FSV Frankfurt]] (loan) | caps2 = 13 | goals2 = 1 | years3 = 2016–2017 | clubs3 = → [[N.E.C. (football club)|NEC]] (loan) | caps3 = 18 | goals3 = 2 | years4 = 2017–2018 | clubs4 = → [[Royal Excel Mouscron]] (loan) | caps4 = 29 | goals4 = 9 | years5 = 2018–2019 | clubs5 = → [[K.A.A. Gent|Gent]] (loan) | caps5 = 16 | goals5 = 0 | years6 = 2019– | clubs6 = → [[Royal Excel Mouscron]] (loan) | caps6 = 7 | goals6 = 6 | pcupdate = 10:08, 1 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalyears1 = 2013 | nationalyears2 = 2015 | nationalyears3 = 2015– | nationalteam1 = [[Nigeria national under-17 football team|Nigeria U17]] | nationalteam2 =[[Nigeria national under-20 football team|Nigeria U20]] | nationalteam3 =[[Nigeria national under-23 football team|Nigeria U23]] | nationalcaps1 = 8 | nationalgoals1 = 4 | nationalcaps2 = 9 | nationalgoals2 = 7 | nationalcaps3 = 3 | nationalgoals3 = 2 | medaltemplates = {{Medal|Competition|[[FIFA U-17 World Cup]]}} {{Medal|Gold| [[2013 FIFA U-17 World Cup]] | }} {{Medal|Competition|[[African U-20 Championship]]}} {{Medal|Gold| [[2015 African U-20 Championship]] | }} | nationalteam-update = 7 September 2015 }} '''Taiwo Micheal Awoniyi''' (born 12 August 1997) is a Nigerian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[Royal Excel Mouscron]] on loan from English [[Premier League]] club [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]. Taiwo's style of play has been compared to that of [[Rashidi Yekini]], Nigeria's all-time highest goalscorer.{{cite web | url=http://www.goal.com/s/en-ng/news/4082/editorial/2015/03/14/9776762/taiwo-awoniyi-the-youngster-looking-to-fill-rashidi-yekinis | title=TAIWO AWONIYI: THE YOUNGSTER LOOKING TO FILL RASHIDI YEKINI'S BIG VOID | work=Goal.com | author=Solace Chukwu | date=14 March 2015 | accessdate=7 September 2015}} ==Club career== ===Early career=== In 2010, Taiwo was voted the Most Valuable Player at a [[Coca-Cola]] football competition in [[London]]. His performance at the competition was spotted by [[Seyi Olofinjana]] who made him join Imperial Soccer Academy.{{cite news | url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2013/11/beat-taiwo-awoniyi-discourage-football-dad/ | title=I beat Taiwo Awoniyi to discourage him from football – Dad | work=[[Vanguard (Nigeria)|Vanguard]] | date=10 November 2013 | accessdate=7 September 2015}} ===Liverpool=== On 31 August 2015, Taiwo signed for [[Liverpool F.C.]] for a fee of around £400,000 but was immediately loaned out to [[FSV Frankfurt]].{{cite news | url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/192974-reds-complete-signing-of-taiwo-awoniyi | title=Reds complete signing of Taiwo Awoniyi | work=[[Liverpool F.C.]] | author=James Carrol | date=31 August 2015 | accessdate=7 September 2015}}{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/aug/31/liverpool-nigeria-taiwo-awoniyi-frankfurt | title=Liverpool sign 18-year-old Nigeria forward Taiwo Awoniyi | work=[[The Guardian]] | author=Press Association | date=31 August 2015 | accessdate=7 September 2015}} ====Loan to FSV Frankfurt==== He made his debut for the club as a late substitute in a German Cup match against [[Hertha Berlin]]. After being named as a substitute for six league matches, he made his debut on 19 February 2016, playing 89 minutes against [[FC St. Pauli]].{{cite news | url=http://www.soccernet.com.ng/2016/02/liverpools-awoniyi-makes-league-debut.html? | title=Liverpool's Awoniyi makes League Debut In Germany| work=Soccernet | author= | date=19 February 2016 | accessdate=19 February 2016}} With the team of the 2. Bundesliga, Awoniyi suffered relegation and was not kept at the end of the season. ====Loan to NEC Nijmegen==== On 26 August 2016, [[N.E.C. (football club)|NEC]] confirmed that he had joined them on a season-long loan and was expected to join the squad the following week after the formalities of his work permit were completed.{{cite news | url=http://www.nec-nijmegen.nl/2016/08/n-e-c-huurt-aanvaller-taiwo-awoniyi/| title=NEC hires striker Taiwo Awoniyi| work=NEC | author= | date=26 August 2016 | accessdate=30 August 2016}} On 10 September, he made his [[Eredivisie]] debut in a 4{{ndash}}0 defeat of NEC to [[PSV Eindhoven]], being replaced in the 72nd minute by [[Michael Heinloth]].{{cite news|url=http://sports.nigeriannation.com/2016/09/10/nwakaeme-hits-hat-trick-enyeama-concedes-four-awoniyi-makes-nec-debut/|title=Nwakaeme Hits Hat-trick, Enyeama Concedes Four, Awoniyi Makes NEC Debut|work=Nigerian Nation|author=Johnny Edward|date=10 September 2016|accessdate=11 September 2016}} With Nijmegen, the Nigerian suffered his second consecutive relegation, being relegated from [[Eredivisie]] in 2017.{{cite web|url=https://nos.nl/artikel/2175441-nec-degradeert-na-forse-nederlaag-tegen-nac.html/|title=NEC degradeert na forse nederlaag tegen NAC|author=|date=28 May 2017|website=nos.nl|accessdate=6 February 2018}} ====Loan to Royal Excel Mouscron==== In July 2017 Awoniyi left Nijmegen and joined Belgian club [[Royal Excel Mouscron]] on a season-long loan, and on his debut on 12 August (also his birthday) started the match against [[KSC Lokeren]] and scored within 23 minutes.{{cite web|url=https://www.thisisanfield.com/2017/08/productive-weekend-liverpool-loanees-taiwo-awoniyi-scores-mouscron-debut/|title=Liverpool loanee celebrates birthday with debut goal|author=|date=13 August 2017|website=thisisanfield.com|accessdate=10 September 2017}} ====Loan to KAA Gent==== On 17 July 2018 he signed a new long-term deal with Liverpool{{cite web |url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/307427-taiwo-awoniyi-new-contract-liverpool |title=Taiwo Awoniyi signs new Liverpool deal |first=James |last=Carroll |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |date=17 July 2018 |accessdate=23 July 2018}} and on 23 July sealed a season-long loan to another Belgian club, [[K.A.A. Gent|KAA Gent]].{{cite web |url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/308567-taiwo-awoniyi-loan-genk |title=Taiwo Awoniyi seals loan switch to KAA Gent |first=James |last=Carroll |publisher=Liverpool F.C. |date=23 July 2018 |accessdate=23 July 2018}} On 11 January 2019, it was announced that his loan to Gent was cut short, and Awoniyi was loaned to Mouscron again.{{cite news |title=Taiwo Awoniyi joins Mouscron on loan |url=https://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/first-team/333718-taiwo-awoniyi-liverpool-mouscron-loan |work=Liverpool FC}} ==International career== Taiwo represented Nigeria at the [[2013 FIFA U-17 World Cup]] and went on to win the tournament, scoring four goals during the competition.{{cite news | url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/taiwo-awoniyi-the-new-bride-of-european-clubs/213228/ | title=Taiwo Awoniyi: The New Bride of European Clubs | work=[[Thisday]] | date=27 June 2015 | accessdate=7 September 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150907093230/http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/taiwo-awoniyi-the-new-bride-of-european-clubs/213228 | archivedate=7 September 2015 | df= }} He also represented Nigeria at the [[2015 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] in [[New Zealand]] after winning the [[2015 African U-20 Championship]] in [[Senegal]].{{cite news | url=https://www.fifa.com/u20worldcup/news/y=2015/m=5/news=friday-nigerian-group-go-for-daring-double-2602976.html | title=Nigeria set sights on daring double | work=[[FIFA|Fédération Internationale de Football Association]] | date=8 May 2015 | accessdate=7 September 2015}} On 12 April 2015, he scored a brace on his debut for the [[Nigeria national under-23 football team|Nigeria U-23 team]] in a match against Zambia, as his team went on to qualify for the [[2015 Africa U-23 Cup of Nations|2015 All African Games]].{{cite news | url=http://www.supersport.com/football/nigeria/news/150412/Nigeria_U23s_qualify_for_AAG | title=Awoniyi brace catapults Nigeria U23 | work=[[SuperSports]] | author=George Akpayen | date=12 April 2015 | accessdate=7 September 2015}} He was selected by Nigeria for their 35-man provisional squad for the 2016 Summer Olympics.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36623763|title=Kelechi Iheanacho included in Nigeria's Olympics squad|date=24 June 2016|accessdate=25 June 2016|author=Oluwashina Okeleji|publisher=BBC Sport}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 26 December 2018}} bestowed with the [[Order of the Niger#Groups|Member of the Order of the Niger]] award.{{cite news | url=http://www.sl10.ng/news/articles/categories/south-africa/kalmar-trainee-taiwo-awoniyi-overjoyed-after-picking-up-mon-award/178212 | title=Awoniyi Overjoyed With MON Award | work=SL10 | date=30 September 2014 | accessdate=7 September 2015}} It was also reported in the media that there were plans by the Kwara State House of Assembly to name a major street after him.{{cite news | url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2014/03/kwara-name-street-taiwo-awoniyi/ | title=Kwara to name street after Taiwo Awoniyi | work=[[Vanguard (Nigeria)|Vanguard]] | author=Demola Akinyemi | date=11 March 2014 | accessdate=7 September 2015}} ==Personal life== He married his partner Taiwo Jesudun in an engagement and traditional wedding in [[Kabba]] on Friday 15 June 2018, followed by a white wedding on 16 June in [[Ilorin]].{{cite news | url=https://www.completesportsnigeria.com/ex-golden-eaglet-taiwo-awoniyi-20-gets-married/ | title=Ex-Golden Eaglet Taiwo Awoniyi, 20, Gets Married | work=Complete
